DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS BOYSIDIA (ANCEY, 1881) FROM CHINA (PULMONATA,
   STYLOMMATOPHORA, PUPILLIDAE).
AU Yang, Hai-Fang
   Zhang, Wei-Hong
   Chen, De-Niu
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 550-551
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the present paper a new species of land snail is described. The
   materials were collected by the authors in Xinyi County, Guizhou
   Province, China, Oct., 2005. Type specimens are deposited in the
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China. Boysidia
   (Boysidia) gongyaoshanensis sp. nov. (Figs 1-3) Holotype. Height 2.30
   mm, diameter 2.00 mm, aperture height 0.80 mm, diameter of shell 0.85
   mm., collected from Gongyao Hill, Xingyi County (25[degree]00[minute]N,
   104[degree]08[minute]E), Guizhou Province, China, 3 Oct. 2005. Paratypes
   38 specimens. Height 2.10-2.40 mm, diameter 1.97-2.10 mm, aperture
   height 0.78-0.84 mm, diameter of shell 0.82-0.87 mm, collected from
   Gongyao Hill, Wanfang, Xingyi County (25[degree]00[minute]N,
   104[degree]08[minute]E), Guizhou Province, China, 3 Oct. 2005.
   Etymology. The name of the new species refers type locality adjective.
   Shell small, thick, lustrous, conic. Whorls 4 1/2, moderately convex,
   spire depressed-conical, embryo-whorls (1-2) smooth, the body whorl very
   inflated. Shell yellowish in colour, regularly and weakly striatulate,
   silk. Apex blunt, suture deep. Aperture rounded-oval, peristome
   reflected, well expanded, continuous, with 6 lamellae and folds: 1 large
   stout, nipple-formed angular lamellae, 1 big flake-formed parietal
   lamellae, 1 bigger nipple-formed columellar lamellae, 1 small
   nipple-formed basal fold, 1 small nipple-formed upper palatal fold, and
   1 small suprapalatal fold. Umbilicus big, with hole-formed. Remarks. The
   new species resembles Boysidia (Boysidia) huangguoshuensis Luo et Chen,
   2000, but in the latter the shell is bigger (height 3.17 mm, diameter
   2.20 mm; aperture of height 1.22 mm, aperture of diameter 1.06 mm), with
   whorls 5 1/2, 4 folds, angular and parietal lamellae united into 1 big
   lobed lamella Habitat. The animals live on limestone walls, love habitat
   as on surface of limestone, locality of moist, bryophyte and lichen or
   lives on chink of orck, under fallen leaves and rotten branch.
C1 Chen, De-Niu; Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Scinces, Beijing
   100101, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Boysidia gongyaoshanensis [Guizhou /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Pupilloidea
OR Boysidia gongyaoshanensis (Pupilloidea): [Sp nov, Guizhou, P. 550].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS HYPOASPIS FROM NINGXIA, CHINA WITH
   SUPPLEMENTARY DESCRIPTION OF HYPOASPIS SUBPICTUS GU ET BAI, 1992 (ACARI,
   LAELAPIDAE).
AU Bai, Xue-Li
   Ma, Li-Ming
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 555-558
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper describes a new species Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) guoi sp.nov.
   (Acari, Laelapidae)and provides made some supplementary description on
   Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) subpictus Gu et Bai, 1992. The type specimens
   of the new species were collected from Haiyuan County of Ningxia Hui
   Autonomous Region, China. All the type specimens are deposited in the
   Collection of the Medical Entomology of Institute of Microbiology and
   Epidemiology Academy of Military Medical Science, Beijing, China.
   Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) guoi sp. nov. (Figs 1-9) Female. The new
   species is similar to Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) subpictus Gu et Bai,
   1992, but can be easily differentiated from the latter by: 1) dorsal
   plate bearing 39 pairs of round leaf-like setae with dot nets and D7 -8
   with one unpaired seta; 2) slightly concaved anterior margin of sternal
   plate and st1 on the palte with two large lyrifissures organs; 3)
   triangle-shaped anal plate with V-shaped spines area on the plate.
   Holotype [female] and paratype 1[female], collected by BAI Xue-Li on 19
   May 1989, from a nest of Myrmos sp. in Haiyuan County (36.5[degree]N,
   105.6[degree]E) of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, China. Etymology. This
   new species is named in honour of Pro. GUO Xian-Guo (Dali University,
   China). Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) subpictusGu et Bai, 1992 (Fig. 10)
   Hypoaspis subpictusGu et Bai, 1992. Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica, 17(2):
   189, figs 12-17. Female. Light yellow. Genito-ventral plate
   tongue-shaped, with one pair of setae as shown in fig. 10. Specimens
   examined. 2[female] [female], collected by BAI Xue-Li on 12 June 1988,
   from a nest of Myrmos sp. in Haiyuan County (36.5[degree]N,
   105.6[degree]E) of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, China.
C1 Bai, Xue-Li; Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region Center for Disease Control
   and Prevention, Yinchuan 750004, China, China.

   Associations; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF METRODORIDAE (ORTHOPTERA) FROM THE NUJIANG GORGE,
   YUNNAN, CHINA.
AU Zheng, Zhe-Min
   Ou, Xiao-Hong (oxh82011@public.km.yn.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 559-563
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper, two new species of Metrodoridae, i.e.,
   Systolederus oculatus sp. nov. and Bolivaritettix gaoligongshanensis sp.
   nov., are described. The type specimens are deposited in the Museum of
   Southwest Forestry University and Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normasl
   University. Systolederus oculatus sp. nov. (Figs 1-3) This new species
   is allied to S. guangxiensis Zheng et Jiang, 1998 and S. emeiensis
   Zheng, 1998, but differs from both in: 1) upper margin of pronotoum
   straight in profile; 2) hind process of poronotum reaching the top of
   hind tibia; 3) hind margin of subgenital plate of female with three
   teeth; 4) hind tibia black, with light ring. It differs from S.
   guangxiensis in: 1) the middle of anterior margin of pronotum slightly
   concave; 2) without a pair short longitudinal keels between shoulders.
   It differs from S. emeiensis in: 1) midkeel of pronotum distinctly the
   whole length; 2) hind wing reaching the top of hind process. Length of
   body: [male] 11.0-12.5 mm; [female]15.0-15.5 mm. Length of pronotuom:
   [male] 10.5-12.5 mm; [female]13.5-14.0 mm. Width if shoulders: [male]
   2.0-2.5 mm; [female] 3.0-3.1 mm. Length of hind femur: [female] 4-5 mm;
   [female]4-5 mm. Holotype [male], Yunnan, Liuku (25[degree]50[minute]N,
   98[degree] 51[minute]E; alt. 770 m), 17 May 2011, collected by LI
   Hui-Jun et al. Paratypes: 4[male] [male], 4 [female] [female], same data
   as holootype; 7[male] [male], 2[female] [female], Yunnan, Liuku, alt.
   730-750 m, 16 May 2011, collected by LI Hui-Jun et al. Etymology. The
   specific name is derived from the Latin "ocula". Bolivaritettix
   gaoligongshanensis sp. nov. (Figs 4-8) This new species is allied to B.
   juwanshanensis Zheng, 2005 and B. lativertex Brunner von Wattenwyl,
   1893, but differs from both in: 1) width of frontal ridge narrower than
   the width of basal segment of antenna ; 2) hind process reaching the two
   third of hind tibia; 3) upper midkeel of hind femur with three
   projections; 4) width of midfemur narrower than the width of tegmina. 5)
   humeral angle of pronotum rounded. It differs from B. juwanshanensis in:
   1) width of vertex 1.5 times that the width of an eye; 2) upper margin
   of pronotum nearly straight in profile; 3) hind wing reaching the top of
   hind process. Length of body: [male]10-11 mm; [female]13.5-14.0 mm.
   Length of pronotuom: [male]13.0-15.5 mm; [female]15-20 mm. Length of
   hind femur: [male] 6.0-6.3 mm; [female] 6.5-10.0 mm. Holotype [female],
   Yunnan, Lushui (26[degree]5[minute]N, 98[degree]5[minute]E; 940 m), 27
   Mar. 2011, collected by LI Hui-Jun; paratypes: 6 [male] [male], 12
   [female] [female], same data as holotype; 1[male], 2[female] [female],
   Yunnan, Lushui (25[degree]39[minute]N, 98[degree] 24[minute]E; alt.
   780m), collected by WU Yu-Xi and LI Jian-Yu. Etymology. The specific
   name is derived from the type locality "Gaoligongshan".
C1 Ou, Xiao-Hong; Key Laboratory of Forest Disaster Warning and Control in
   Yunnan Province, Southwest Forestry University, Kunming 650224, China,
   China.
EM oxh82011@public.km.yn.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Bolivaritettix gaoligongshanensis; Systolederus oculatus [Yunnan /  /
   New species].

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS CHORTHIPPUS (ORTHOPTERA, ARCYPTERIDAE) FROM
   XINJIANG, CHINA.
AU Wang, Yan-Feng
   Zheng, Zhe-Min (wyfcollege@sohu.com)

VL 37

PS 570-572
PD July 2012

U2 0
AB In this paper, a new species of Chorthippu kanasensis sp. nov.
   (Orthoptera, Arcypteridae) is described from the Kanas Lake, North of
   Xinjiang, China. The type specimens are deposited in the Institute of
   Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University.

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF CORRUGIA MALAISE (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) FROM
   GUANGXI WITH A KEY TO KNOWN ASIAN SPECIES OF THE GENUS.
AU Liu, Yan-Xia
   Xiao, Wei
   Wei, Mei-Cai (weimc@126.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 573-576
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of Corrugia Malaise (Hymenoptera, Tenthredinidae)
   Tenthredinidae from Guangxi, China are described. A key to Asian species
   of the genus is provided. The type specimens are kept in the Insect
   Collection of Central South University of Forestry and Technology,
   Changsha, Hunan Province, China (CSCS) and the Insect Collection of
   China Agricultural University, Beijing, China (CAUB). 1 Corrugia liaoae
   Wei et Liu, sp. nov. (Figs 1[long dash]4) Body length of female 5 mm,
   male unknown. This new species is similar to C. montana (Forsius, 1933)
   but differs from the latter in the lateral fovea round and not extending
   inwards, area between the two lateral foveae distinctly elevated; basal
   two antennomeres brown, the hind tibia with an apical black spot, and
   wings evenly infuscate. Holotype ?, Guangxi, Mt. Mao'er, Jiuniutang
   (25[degree]53[minute]N, 110[degree]26[minute]E; alt. 1980 m), 9 June
   2006, LIAO Fang-Jun (CSCS). Paratype 1[female], Guangxi, Wuming, Mt.
   Daming, 23 May 1963, YANG Ji-Kun (CAUB). Etymology. The new species is
   named after the surname of collector of the holotype. 2 Corrugia
   curvatispina Wei et Xiao, sp. nov. (Figs 5[long dash]8) Body length of
   female 7 mm, male unknown. This new species is similar to Corrugia
   liaoae sp. nov., but differs from the latter in the basal 2 antennomeres
   black; head in dorsal view 2 times as broad as long, frons with distinct
   lateral carina, the distance between antennal sockets 1.2 times as broad
   as the distance between antennal socket and inner orbit; antenna as long
   as head and thorax together, second antennomere distinctly shorter than
   the first antennomere, third antennomere distinctly longer than apical 3
   antennomeres together; female lancet with distinctly sclerotized annular
   sutures, dorsal membrane of lancet very broad, apical process of lancet
   distinctly bent and obtuse at apex. Holotype [female], Guangxi, Wuming,
   Mt. Daming, Longwei Waterfall (23[degree]29[minute]N,
   108[degree]25[minute]E; alt. 1155m), 27 May 2011, LIU Yan-Xia, XUE
   Jun-Zhe (CSCS). Etymology. The new species is named after the distinctly
   curved apical spina of lancet.
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Lab of Insect Systematics and Evolutionary Biology,
   Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha 410004,
   China, China.

DT Article
TI ON THE GENUS BRYKELLA MALAISE (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) WITH
   DESCRIPTIONS OF TWO NEW SPECIES FROM CHINA.
AU Wei, Mei-Cai (weimc@126.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 584-588
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of Brykella Malaise from China are described. Keys to
   genera of the tribe Anisoarthrini and to known species of Brykella are
   provided. The type specimens are kept in the Insect Collection of
   Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan
   Province, China (CSCS) and Institute of Zoology, the Chinese Academy of
   Sciences (IZCS). 1 Brykella albofemorata sp. nov. (Figs 1[long dash]11)
   Body length of female 10 mm, male unknown. This new species is similar
   to B. tamdaoensis Haris, 2008 from Vietnam, but differs from the latter
   in each femur entirely white; the first abdominal tergite largely yellow
   white with only lateral sides reddish brown; the abdominal sternites
   dark reddish brown; the smoky macula in forewing much darker in anterior
   half; the fourth tooth of claw short and obtuse at apex, not
   differentiated completely from the basal lobe. Holotype [female],
   Guangxi, Wuming, Mt. Damingshan, Longteng Hotel (23[degree]29[minute]N,
   108[degree]25[minute]E; alt. 1368 m), 23 May 2011, LIU Yan-Xia, XUE
   Jun-Zhe (CSCS). Paratypes: 1[female], same data as holotype; 1[female],
   Yunnan, Xishuangbanna, Mengsong, alt. 1600 m, 24 Apr. 1958, PU Fu-Ji
   (IZCS). Etymology. This new species is named after its white femora. 2
   Brykella magna sp. nov. (Figs 12[long dash]21) Body length of female 13
   mm, male unknown. This new species is similar to B. brevis Wei, 2003
   from Fujian but differs from the latter in body length 13 mm; the cell
   2Rs on forewing distinctly longer than cells 1R1+1Rs together; the hind
   basitarsus as long as following 4 tarsomeres together; the setae on
   lateral sides of sheath in dorsal view extending more outwards with an
   angle at about 90[degrees][long dash]100[degrees]; the middle trochanter
   black brown; the second tooth of claw longer than the first one, the
   fourth tooth distinct and acute at apex; the petiole of hind anal cell
   longer than half length of the anal cell and about 1.8 times length of
   vein cu-a. Holotype [female], Guangxi, Wuming, Mt. Daming, Liangjiang
   Town (23[degree]54[minute]N, 108[degree]35[minute]E; alt. 200 m), 26 May
   2011, LIU Yan-Xia, XUE Jun-Zhe. Paratypes: 1[female], same data as
   holotype; 1[female], Guangxi, Fangchenggang, alt. 250 m, 7 Apr. 2002,
   CAI Ping (CSCS). Etymology. The species is named after its large body
   size.
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Lab of Insect Systematics and Evolutionary Biology,
   Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha 410004,
   China, China.
EM weimc@126.com

DT Article
TI THREE NEW SPECIES OF BELESESINAE (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) FROM
   CHINA.
AU Niu, Geng-Yun
   Xue, Jun-Zhe
   Wei, Mei-Cai (weimc@126.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 589-595
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three new species of Belesesinae of Tenthredinidae are described:
   Beleses latimaculata Wei et Niu, sp. nov., B. nigropilosa Wei et Niu,
   sp. nov. and Eusunoxa fulvitarsus Wei et Xue, sp. nov. The type
   specimens are kept in the Insect Collection of Central South University
   of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan Province, China. 1 Beleses
   latimaculata Wei et Niu, sp. nov. (Figs 1-10) Body length. Female 9 mm,
   male 7 mm. This new species is close to Beleses multipictus (Rohwer,
   1916), but differs from the latter in the mesepisternum with one white
   stripe only; the white stripe on inner orbit linear at middle; the inner
   margins of eyes strongly convergent downwards; the ventral black stripe
   on hind coxa broad and not broadened at apex; the middle serrulae of
   female lancet with 3-4 proximal teeth and 13-14 distal teeth. This
   species was identified as Beleses multipictus (Rohwer, 1916) (Wei and
   Nie, 2002). The examination of the holotype of Beleses multipictus
   (Rohwer, 1916) shows that the species identified as Beleses multipictus
   from the mainland of China is an undescribed species. Holotype [female],
   Guangxi, Wuming, Beihuiguixian (Tropic of Cancer)
   (23[degree]23[minute]N, 108[degree]26[minute]E; alt.1300m), 20 May 2011,
   LIU Yan-Xia, XUE Jun-Zhe. Paratypes: 1[male], Hainan, Mt. Jiangfeng, 21
   July 1997, WEI Mei-Cai; 1[female], 1[male], Guangxi, Mt. Mao'er, alt.
   1000m, 24 June 1999, XIAO Wei; 1[female], Hubei, Wufeng, Houhe, 11 July
   1999, DENG Tie-Jun; 1[female], 1[male], Hunan, Shimen, Mt. Huping, July
   1994, LIU Zhi-Wei; 1[female], Fujian, Mt. Wuyi, Dazhulan, alt.
   1000-1300m, 19 May 2004, ZHOU Hu; 1[female], Hunan, Mt. Huping,
   Jiangping, alt. 1200-1600m, 9 June 2004, JIANG Yang; 1[female], Guangxi,
   Rongshui, Mt. Yuanbao, alt. 900m, 22 July 2001, XIAO Wei; 1[female],
   Hunan, Wugang, Mt. Yun, alt. 1100m, 4 June 2003, HE Ying-Ke; 1[female],
   Guangdong, Ruyuan, Qinshuigu (24[degree]54[minute]N,
   113[degree]02[minute]E; alt. 824m), 15 May 2007, YOU Qun; 1[female],
   Guangxi, Mt. Mao'er, Jiuniutang (25[degree]53[minute]N,
   110[degree]22[minute]E; alt. 1164m), 22 Apr. 2006, YOU Qun; 1[female],
   Guangxi, Mt. Mao'er, Guanjingtai (25[degree]52[minute]N,
   110[degree]29[minute]E; alt. 926m), 18 May 2006, LIAO Fang-Jun;
   1[female], Guangxi, Mt. Mao'er, Hongjunting (25[degree]54[minute]N,
   110[degree]27[minute]E; alt. 1570m), 12 July 2006, LIAO Fang-Jun;
   1[female], Chongqing, Qianjiang, Mt. Wuling, alt. 1000 m, 20 May 2007,
   ZHANG Wei-Wei; 1[male], Chongqing, Jiangjin, Mt. Simian, 15 May 2007,
   ZHANG Wei-Wei; 1[male], Hunan, Mt. Dawei, Limuqiao
   (28[degree]25[minute]N, 114[degree]05[minute] ; alt. 980 m), 5 May 2010,
   LI Ze-Jian; 1?, Shaanxi, Liuba, Sangyuanlinchang
   (33[degree]44.937[minute]N, 107[degree]08.343[minute]E, alt. 1250 m), 18
   May 2007, JIANG Xiao-Yu. Etymology. The specific epithet refers to the
   white stripe on the lower mesepisternum. 2 Beleses nigropilosa Wei et
   Niu, sp. nov. (Figs 11-20) Body length. Female 9 mm, male 8 mm. This new
   species is close to Beleses brachypilosis Wei, 2003, but differs from
   the latter in body including antennae and legs with very long spines,
   which are about as long as scape; head in dorsal side without distinct
   puncture; antenna, anterior and middle trochanters black; serrulae with
   minute teeth; the apical and subapical serrulae roundly convex; lance
   with dense annular spines, the dorsal margin of the subapical part of
   lance strongly curved. Holotype [female], Guangxi, Wuming,
   Liangjiangzhen (23[degree]54[minute]N, 108[degree]35[minute]E; alt.
   200m), 26 May 2011, LIU Yan-Xia, XUE Jun-Zhe. Paratypes: 1[female], same
   data as holotype; 1[female], Chongqing, Jiangjin, Mt. Simian, 17 June
   2006, ZHANG Wei-Wei; 1[male], Hunan, Shimen, 9 June 1994, LIU Zhi-Wei;
   2[male] [male], Guangdong, Shixing, Chebaling (24[degree]40[minute]N,
   114[degree]09[minute]E; alt. 400m), 20 June 2007, YOU Qun, LIAO
   Fang-Jun. Etymology. This species is named after its black body hairs. 3
   Eusunoxa fulvitarsus Wei et Xue, sp. nov. (Figs 21-27) Body length.
   Female 7.0 mm, male 5.8-6.5 mm. This new species is close to Eusunoxa
   formosana Enslin, 1911 but differs from the latter in hind tarsus dark
   yellow brown; malar space in female 0.9 times diameter of the middle
   ocellus; postocellar area 2.5 times as broad as long; the lateral
   furrows of postocellar area distinctly longer than diameter of lateral
   ocellus, distinctly divergent backwards; apex of apical sheath acute in
   lateral view. Holotype [female], Yunnan, Mt. Wuliang, Qincaitang
   (24[degree]18[minute]N, 100[degree]43[minute]E; alt. 2197m), 14 July
   2006, YANG Qing. Paratypes: 1[male], Guizhou, Maolan, Sanchahe, alt.
   750m, 11 May 1999, WEI Mei-Cai; 2 [male] [male], Guizhou, Libo, Banzhai,
   alt. 800m, 1 Aug. 1999, WEI Mei-Cai, BU Wen-Jun; 1[male], Sichuan, Mt.
   Emei, Xixiangchi, 19 July 2001, WEI Mei-Cai; 1[male], Guangxi, Baise,
   Leye, alt. 1100m, 7 July 1999, XIAO Wei; 1[female], Zhejiang, Anji, Mt.
   Longwang, 23 July 1999, WU Hong; 1[female], Hunan, Mt. Huping, July
   1994, LIU Zhi-Wei (Malaise trap); 1[male], Guangxi, Wuming, Mt. Daming,
   Chuichenfeng (23[degree]30[minute]N, 108[degree]26[minute]E; alt.
   1230m), 9 Aug. 2011, LIU Yan-Xia. Etymology. This species is named after
   its yellow brown hind tarsus.
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Lab of Insect Systematics and Evolutionary Biology,
   Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha 410004,
   China, China.

   Guangxi Zhuang, Host not given, p. 592]. 
   Eusunoxa fulvitarsis - Wei &  Xue 2012 (Tenthredinidae): [Sp nov,
   Yunnan, Host not given, p. 593].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF GENUS TRITNEPTIS GIRAULT (HYMENOPTERA, PTEROMALIDAE)
   PARASITIZING PRISTIPHORA ERICHSONII (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) WITH A
   KEY TO FOUR KNOWN SPECIES IN CHINA.
AU Yang, Zhong-Qi
   Xia, Gu-Cheng
   Cao, Liang-Ming
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 596-601
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of genus Tritneptis Girault 1908, T. liupanshanensis Yang
   sp. nov., belonging to Pteromalidae (Hymenoptera) is described from
   China. It is a gregarious ectoparasitoid in the prepupa and/or pupa of
   sawfly Pristiphora erichsonii (Hartig) (Hymenoptera, Tenthredinidae), a
   serious defoliator pest of larch trees in Northern China. The new
   species is a dominating natural enemy on the pest with parasitism rate
   26.8% in the overwinter prepupae of the sawfly. From a single host 18-74
   wasps of the parasitoid were reared out with female and male ratio
   6.2:1.0. It played an important role in regulating its host population
   naturally in the larch forests (Larix principis-rupprechtii) of
   Liupanshan Mountains, and it has a potential as a biological control
   agent. The characters of the new species are described. A key to four
   species of the genus known in China is provided. The biology of the new
   species is briefly described too. Type specimens are deposited in the
   Insect Collection of Chinese Academy of Forestry, Beijing, China.
   Tritneptis liupanshanensis Yang, sp. nov. (Figs 1-10) The new species is
   similar to T. affinis (Nees, 1834), but can be distinguished from the
   latter by the key below. From other 2 Chinese species T. macrocentri
   Liao, 1987 and T. klugii (Ratzeburg, 1844) it can be also separated by
   the key. Key to four Chinese species of Tritneptis Girault (female).1.
   Antennal insertion on the lower ocular line, 2nd anellus short and as
   long as the 1st; parasitizing larva of Macrocentrus sp. (Braconidae)
   ........................................................................
   .................................................................T.
   macrocentri Liao Antennal insertion below lower ocular line, 2nd anellus
   subquadrate and distinctly longer than the 1st; parasitizing other
   hosts..........22. Forewing with marginal vein 1.75-2.00 times as long
   as stigma vein; metasoma with length 2.25-2.70 times its width, and
   width less than mesosoma; temples only about one quarter as long as eye
   length...............................................T. klugii
   (Ratzeburg)Forewing with marginal vein at least 2.3 times as long as
   stigma vein; metasoma relatively short with length below 2.0 times its
   width, and width greater than mesosoma; temples more than half as long
   as eye
   length............................................................33.
   Forewing with marginal vein 2.5-3.0 times as long as stigma vein;
   metasoma with length 1.1-1.4 times its width and only slightly longer
   than mesosoma; metasoma only reddish brown
   basally.................................................................
   ..T. affinis (Nees) Forewing with marginal vein 2.3 times as long as
   stigma vein (Fig. 9); metasoma with length 1.6 times its width, its
   length 1.1 times combined length of mesosoma plus head; whole metasoma
   dark reddish brown (Fig. 10)......T. liupanshanensis Yang sp. nov.
   Holotype [female], Liupanshan Forest Farm, Guyuan, Ningxia, collecting
   cocoons of sawfly Pristiphora erichsonii (Hartig) on 1 May 2010, wasp
   emerged on 15 June 2010, XIA Gu-Cheng and YANG Zhong-Qi. Paratypes: 30
   [female] [female], 12[male] [male], emerged 15 May 2009, LIANG Xing-Ru
   and SUN Pu; 116 [female] [female], 36 [male] [male], 1 May 2010,
   collecting cocoons of its host, wasps emerged 11-30 May 2010, XIA
   Gu-Cheng and YANG Zhong-Qi; 30 [female] [female], 8 [male] [male],
   collecting cocoons of its host on 28 Apr. 2011, wasps emerged on 10 May
   2011, XIA Gu-Cheng and YANG Zhong-Qi. All paratypes were reared from the
   cocoons of Pristiphora erichsonii (Hartig), and the same forest as
   holotype. Etymology. The new species name is derived from the locality
   of its finding, Liupanshan Forest Farm, Ningxia, China.
C1 Yang, Zhong-Qi; Key Lab of Forest Protection of China State Forestry
   Administration, Research Institute of Forest Ecology, Environment and
   Protection, Chinese Academy of Forestry, Beijing 100091, China, China.
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Pristiphora erichsonii [Hymenopteran parasites / Tritneptis
   liupanshanensis / New parasite species] [Ningxia Hui /  / New
   hymenopteran parasite species]. 
   Tritneptis [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Tritneptis liupanshanensis [Hymenopteran hosts / Pristiphora erichsonii
   / New parasite species] [Ningxia Hui /  / New species from hymenopteran
   host]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Chalcidoidea, Pteromalidae, Symphyta, Tenthredinoidea, Tenthredinidae
OR Tritneptis - Girault 1908 (Pteromalidae): [Key to species, China, P.
   598]. 
   Tritneptis liupanshanensis (Pteromalidae): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui,
   Parasite of Pristiphora erichsonii (Hymenoptera), p. 598; Parasite]. 
   Pristiphora erichsonii (Tenthredinidae): [Host].

AN ZOOR14811075031
DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF TOWNESIA (HYMENOPTERA, ICHNEUMONIDAE) FROM CHINA.
AU Liu, Jing-Xian
   He, Jun-Hua (jhhe@zju.edu.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 602-605
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Townesia cheni sp. nov. from Mt. West Tianmu of Zhejiang Province in
   Chinais described and illustrated. A key to the known species of
   Townesia is given. Morphological descriptions, host and distribution are
   also provided. Type specimen is deposited in the Collection of Parasitic
   Hymenoptera of Zhejiang University (ZJU). Townesia cheni sp. nov. (Figs
   1[long dash]8) This species is similar to Townesia tenuiventris, but
   differs from the latter in following characters: 1) ventral valve of
   ovipositor with 7 weak ridges, not produced into backwardly directed
   teeth (the latter species with strong oblique ridges produced into
   backwardly directed teeth); 2) second and third epipleuruon 9.1 times as
   long as wide (the latter 4.0-5.0 times); 3) second to fifth tergites
   without lateral swellings (the latter species with large and distinct
   swellings). It is also distinguished from T. exilis Gupta&Tikar, 1976 by
   having propodeum without longitudinal groove (the latter species with a
   deep longitudinal groove in the centre in basal 0.75); first tergite
   shorter than the second (the latter species with first tergite as long
   as the second). The species can be separated from T. qinghaiensis He,
   1996 by second to fifth tergites without lateral swellings (the latter
   species with distinct swellings); forewing with cu-a vein basad of 1M
   vein (the latter species opposite); ridges of ventral valve of
   ovipositor not produced into backwardly directed teeth (the latter
   species produced into backwardly directed teeth). Holotype. Female,
   China, Zhejiang Province, Mt. West Tianmu, Laodian-Xianrending, alt.
   1150[long dash]1506m, 17-18 May 1988, CHEN Xue-Xin, No. 882277.
   Etymology. The species is named after the collector Prof. CHEN Xue-Xin,
   Institute of Insect Sciences, Zhejiang University.
C1 He, Jun-Hua; Institute of Insect Sciences, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou
   310058, China, China.
EM jhhe@zju.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Townesia cheni [Zhejiang /  / New species].

   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae

   Townesia cheni (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Zhejiang, Host not given, p.
   603].

DT Article
TI SPECIES OF ICHNEUMONIDAE (HYMENOPTERA) PARASITIZING ORGYIA ERICAE WITH
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Sheng, Mao-Ling (shengmaoling@163.com) 
   Zhao, Rui-Xing
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 606-610
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four species of Ichneumonidae, Eutanyacra picta (Schrank), Itoplectis
   viduata (Gravenhorst), Pimpla disparis Viereck, and a new species,
   Dichrogaster orgyiae Sheng, sp. nov. (Figs 1-7), reared from Orgyia
   ericae Germar in Ningxia and Inner Mongolia, are reported. Type
   specimens are deposited in the Insect Museum, General Station of Forest
   Pest Management, State Forestry Administration, People's Republic of
   China. Dichrogaster orgyiae Sheng, sp. nov. (Figs 1-7) Etymology. The
   specific name is derived from the host's name. This new species is
   similar to D. parva Yoshida et Konishi, 2008, but the female can be
   distinguished from the latter ([female]) in having face particularly
   wide, approximately 2.4 times as wide as long, punctures indistinct;
   frons with fine coriaceous texture and fine indistinct punctures; areola
   2.0 times as wide as long, connecting costula at its middle; areolet
   receiving vein 2m-cu about at 0.3 distance from vein 2rs-m to 3rs-m;
   teeth of lower valve of ovipositor indistinct; flagella black, ventral
   profile slightly brownish; anterior portion of tergum 3 brown, posterior
   portion and the following terga black. D. parva (male unknown): face is
   not particularly wide, approximately 1.9 times as wide as long, with
   dense punctures; frons with fine and distinct punctures, the space
   between punctures smooth; areola 2.5 times as wide as long, connecting
   costula approximately at its posterior 0.33; areolet receiving vein
   2m-cu about at its middle; lower valve of ovipositor with nine distinct
   teeth; tergum 3 brown, tergum 4 and the following terga dark brown.
   Holotype [male], Zhungerqi, alt. 1040m, Inner Mongolia, 24 Aug. 2007,
   SHENG Mao-Ling. Paratypes: 1[male], hangjinqi, alt. 1200m, Inner
   Mongolia, 8 Sep. 2007, SHENG Mao-Ling; 1[male], Yanchi, alt. 1380m,
   Ningxia, 17 Aug. 2009, WU Jin-Xia; 1[female], Zhungerqi, alt. 1040m,
   Inner Mongolia, 13 Sep. 2007, SHENG Mao-Ling. Host. Orgyia ericae
   Germar. Eutanyacra picta (Schrank, 1776) Ichneumon pictus Schrank, 1776.
   Beytrage zur Naturgeschichte (Leipzig), 1776: 88. Material examined.
   1[female], 1[male] (reared from Orgyia ericae Germar), Dongsheng, alt.
   1380m, Inner Mongolia, 7-10 June 2006, SHENG Mao-Ling. 1[female] (reared
   from Orgyia ericae Germar), Erduosi, alt. 1310m, Inner Mongolia, 12 July
   2008, SHENG Mao-Ling. Pimpla disparis Viereck, 1911 Pimpla disparis
   Viereck, 1911. Proceedings of the United States National Museum, 40:
   480. Material examined. 3[female] [female], 1[male] (reared from Orgyia
   ericae Germar), Erduosi, alt. 1380m, Inner Mongolia, 15 Sep. to 6 Nov.
   2006, SHENG Mao-Ling; 1[female], 2[male] [male] (reared from Zeiraphera
   grisecana (Hubner)), Liupanshan, Ningxia, 18-30 July 1990; 1[female],
   3[male] [male] (reared from Zeiraphera grisecana (Huebner)), Liupanshan,
   Ningxia, 28-30 July 1991; 4[female] [female], 3[male] [male] (reared
   from Dioryctria pryeri Ragonot), Shenyang, Liaoning, 20-29 June 1996,
   SHENG Mao-Ling; 4[female] [female], 3[male] [male] (reared from D.
   pryeri Ragonot), Shenyang, Liaoning, 13-14 Aug. 2007, SHENG Mao-Ling.
   Itoplectis viduata (Gravenhorst, 1829) Pimpla viduata Gravenhorst, 1829.
   Ichneumonologia Europaea, 3: 214. Material examined. 1[female], (reared
   from Dioryctria pryeri Ragonot), Shenyang, Liaoning, 24 May 1990, SHENG
   Mao-Ling; 4[female] [female] (reared from Orgyia ericae Germar),
   Dongsheng, Inner Mongolia, 13 Sep. 2006, SHENG Mao-Ling; 4[female]

   Ningxia, 30 Aug. 2007; 7[female] [female], 1[male] (reared from Orgyia
   ericae Germar), Dongsheng, Inner Mongolia, 18 June 2008, SHENG Mao-Ling

   Forestry Administration, Shenyang 110034, China, China.

DT Article
TI THE EVOLUTIONARY SIGNIFICANCE ON FR/FA RATIO AND OTHER RELATED CHRACTERS
   OF CHRYSOTUS MEIGEN, 1824 (DIPTERA, DOLICHOPODIDAE, DIAPHORINAE), WITH
   DESCRIPTIONS OF ONE NEW GENUS AND FIVE NEW SPECIES.
AU Wei, Lian-Meng (wlm510520@sina.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 611-622
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the present paper, a group of species separated from Chrysotus
   Meigen, 1824 is establishied as new genus, Dubius gen. nov., of which
   five new species from Guizhou, Southwestern China are described: D.
   autumnalus sp. nov., D. curtus sp. nov., D. frontus sp. nov., D.
   hongyaensis sp. nov. and D. succurtus sp. nov. It may be reasonable
   conjecture that Dubius gen. nov. derives from the Southern land
   (Gondwana land) and spreads to Oriental Region because of the new genus
   is only found in Neotropical Realm and Southwestern China belonging to
   Oriental Region. Dubius gen. nov. Size small. Antennae black, is
   situated at mid and lower part of head. First fragellomere short and
   small, length shorter than width. Arista apically, short pubescent. 6
   dc. Irregularly paired acr short and hair-like. Scutellum with 2 pairs
   of bristles, basal pair short and hair-like. Propleuron with 1 black
   hair and 1 black bristle on lower part. Mid and hind coxae each with 1
   outer bristle. Claws usually present. Pulvilii as a rule undeveloped.
   R4+5 and M parallel apically. CuAx ratio more than 0.3 (sometimes that
   in Neotropical Region with CuAx ratioreach up to 0.7). Halter yellow to
   dark yellow, individual brownish black. Tg6 with setulae. St8 without
   strong long bristles. Epandrium round posteriorly. Surstylus usually
   tapering and slightly curved apically, but Neotropical ones remarkably
   straight. Cercus is small lob-like, unfurcated. Lateral epandrial lobe
   developed. Hypandrium usually expanded and with process apically. Type
   species: Dubius curtus sp. nov. The new genus is allied to Chrysotus
   Meigen, 1824, but differs in: 1) body larger; 2) the formation of frons
   and face as in Diaphorus Meigen, 1824 (frons narrow, and face wider,
   slightly concaved and parallel-sided, fr/fa ratio usually less than
   1.0); 3) antennae is situated at mid and lower part of head. Etymology.
   The new genus name is from the Latin word "Dubius", in reference to the
   variation of frons. Key to the species of Dubius gen. nov. 1 Fr/fa ratio
   more than 1.0. Antennae is situated at mid and upper part of head Arista
   apical. Wing small size, anal field undeveloped. Male: Tg6 setose. St8
   without strong long bristles. Lateral epandrial lobe usually developed.
   Epandrial lobe absent. Claws generally present. Pulvilii usually
   undeveloped ............................................. Chrysotus
   Meigen, 1824 Fr/fa ratio less than or equal to 1.0; not with the above
   combination of characters............2 2 Arista adorsal. Wing large
   sized, anal field developed. Male: Tg6 setose. St8 with 2[long dash]8
   strong long bristles. Lateral epandrial lobe absent. Epandrial lobe
   developed. Claws small or absent. Pulvilii
   developed............................................................Dia
   phorus Meigen, 1824 Arista apical. Wing small sized, anal field
   undeveloped. Male: Tg6 setose, St8 without strong long bristles. Lateral
   epandrial lobe developed. Epandrial lobe absent. Claws and pulvilii
   usually present (Dubius gen.
   nov.)...................................................................
   ..3 3 Fr/fa ratio equal to 1.0. Pulvilii usually
   undeveloped................................................4 Fr/fa ratio
   less than 1.0. Pulvilii usually
   developed...................................................5 4 Frons
   and face as narrow as line. Wing and Tg2[long dash]5 without spot. Male
   with lateral epandrial lobe
   developed...............................................................
   D. autumnalus sp. nov. Frons and face equal in width, broad, around 1.5
   times higher than broad. Wing with a transverse brown spot. Tg2[long
   dash]5 with lateral yellow spots. Male with lateral epandrial lobe
   undeveloped ............................................................
   D. maculatus (Parent, 1930) 5 Abdomen covered with yellow pruinosity.
   St2[long dash]4 covered by long pale setae. Male with lateral epandrial
   lobe
   undeveloped.............................................................
   .................6 Abdomen covered with grey pruinosity. St2[long dash]4
   covered by long pale setae. Male with lateral epandrial lobe
   developed...............................................................
   ..................10 6 Palpus black. Fr/fa ratio less than
   0.20...............................................................7
   Palpus mainly or entirely yellow. Fr/fa ratio more than
   0.41....................................8 7 Fr/fa ratio
   0.20............................................................D.
   spectabilis (Loew, 1861) A Fr/fa ratio
   0.05............................................................D.
   spectabilis (Loew, 1861) B 8 Fore coxa with only white setulae. Frons
   partly greenish with yellowish pollen..................
   ........................................................................
   D. angustifrons (Robinson, 1975) Fore coxa with black setae distally.
   Frons mostly obscured by gray pollen........................9 9 Fore
   coxa and femur mostly yellow....................................D.
   wirthi (Robinson, 1975) Fore coxa and femur mostly brown or
   greenish.....................D. robustus (Robinson, 1975) 10 5 dc. Mid
   tibiae without pd...................................................D.
   hongyaensis sp. nov. 1. Dubius autumnalus sp. nov. (Figs. 14, 16) Male
   Body length about 2.4 mm; wing length about 2.2 mm. The new species with
   face as narrow as frons, which is a unique feature in Dubius gen. nov.
   and may be represent a new evolutionary direction in Dubius gen. nov.
   Holotype [male], Guizhou: Anshun, Longgong, 1200 m,
   (26[degree]05.5[minute] N, 105[degree]52.5[minute] E; alt. 1200 m), 3
   July 1994, WEI Lian-Meng. Etymology. From the Latin autumnal, meaning
   "autumn".2. Dubius curtus sp. nov. (Figs. 11, 17, 21) Male Body length
   about 2.8 mm; wing length about 2.5 mm. The new species closely related
   to D. succurtus sp. nov., but can be separated from each other by the
   couplets in the key. Holotype [male], Laogao village Guanling, Guizhou,
   (25[degree]53.5[minute]N, 105[degree] 38.4[minute]E), alt. 600 m, 20,
   April, 2008; paratypes 7 [male] [male], same locality as holotype, WEI
   Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, JIANG Shao-Gui and WANG De-Xiang; 5 [male]
   [male], Putunba, Bulang, Puding, Guizhou, alt. 1500 m, 26, April, 2008,
   WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping and JIANG Shao-Gui; 1[male], Langfengguan,
   Ziyun, Guizhou, alt. 900 m, 6, April, 2008, WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping
   and JIANG Shao-Gui; 1[male], Hongyabei, Guanling, Guizhou, alt. 900 m,
   12[long dash]13, April, 2008, WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, JIANG
   Shao-Gui, LIU Mei-Hua and XIAO Qian-Lin. Etymology. The specific name is
   from the Latin word "curtus", meaning "curved". 3. Chrysotus frontus sp.
   nov. (Figs 17-18) Male Body length about 2.2 mm; wing length about 2.3
   mm. The new species related to D. succurtus sp. nov. and D. curtus sp.
   nov., but these three new species can be separated from each other by
   the couplets 11 in the key. Type material. Holotype [male], Guizhou:
   Maolan, Raolan, 600-650m, 25[degree]15[minute] N, 107[degree]45[minute]
   E, 19-20. VI. 2006, YANG Zai-Hua. Etymology. From the Latin "frons,
   meaning new species with frons marrow. 4. Dubius hongyaensis sp. nov.
   (Figs 10, 19, 22) Male Body length about 2.8 mm; wing length about 2.6
   mm. Related to D. curtus sp. nov., but can be separated from the latter
   by the couplets in the key. Holotype [male], Hongyabei, Guanling,
   Guizhou (25[degree]56.6[minute]N, 105[degree]39.1[minute]E), alt. 900 m,
   20, April, 2008; paratypes 3 [male] [male], same locality as holotype,
   WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, JIANG Shao-Gui, WANG De-Xiang and JIN Wei;
   1 [male], Wula village, Huangguoshu, Guizhou, alt. 1000 m, 19[long
   dash]25, April, 2008; 1 [male], WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, JIANG
   Shao-Gui; 1 [male], Laogao village, Guanling, Guizhou, alt. 600 m, 18,
   April, 2008, WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, JIANG Shao-Gui. Etymology. The
   specific name is from the the type locality-Hongya, Guanling, Guizhou.
   5. Dubius succurtus sp. nov. (Figs. 9, 20, 23) Male Body length about
   3.3 mm; wing length about 3.0 mm. Related to D. curtus sp. nov., but can
   be separated from each other by the couplets in the key. Holotype
   [male], Gaopo, Jiangzhou, Duyun, Guizhou, alt. 1500 m, Aug. to Sept.,
   2011, WEI Lian-Meng, CAO Wei-Ping, SHOU Tian-Hong, JIN Peng and LONG
   Shu-Weng; paratypes 2 [male] [male], same locality as holotype, Jun. to
   Jul., 2011, WEI Lian-Meng, WEI Lian-Jian, CAO Wei-Ping, LONG Biao, WANG
   Qing-Da, LI Zao-Qian and LUO Ming-Jian. Etymology. The specific name is
   from the Latin word "curtus", meaning "curved", and "suc" meaning "to be
   close to ", in reference to its similarity to D. curtus sp. nov.

TI NOTE ON THE GENUS CITROGRAMMA VOCKEROTH FROM CHINA (DIPTERA, SYRPHIDAE).
AU Huo, Ke-Ke
   Pan, Zhao-Hui
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 623-631
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper recorded 11 species of the genus Citrogramma Vockeroth, 1969
   from China, including one new species: Citrogramma xizangensis sp. nov.,
   C. amarilla Mengual, C.arisanicum (Shiraki), C. citrinoides Wyatt, C.
   citrinum (Brunetti), C. clarum (Herve-Bazin), C. currani Ghorpade, C.
   fumipenne (Matsumura), C.gedehanum(de Meijere), C. matsumurai Mengual
   and C. shirakii Mengual. The studied specimens are preserved in the
   Museum of Animal and Botany, Shaanxi University of Technology.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES AND TWO NEW RECORD SPECIES OF THE GENUS PSILOPA FROM CHINA
   (DIPTERA, EPHYDRIDAE).
AU Zhou, Dan
   Yang, Ding
   Zhang, Jun-Hua (zjhcome@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 632-636
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the paper, a new species and two new record species of the genus
   Psilopa Fallen (Diptera, Ephydridae) are described: P. wangi sp. nov.,
   P. marginella (Fallen, 1823) and P. leucostoma (Meigen, 1830). P.
   marginella and P. leucostoma distribute in Helan Mountain of Inner
   Mongolia in China. The types are deposited in the Entomological Museum
   of China Agricultural University, Beijing. Psilopa wangi Zhou, Yang et
   Zhang, sp. nov. (Figs 1-5) This new species is allied to P. marginella
   (Fallen, 1823), but differs from the latter in the following points: 1)
   face bare without microtomentum; 2) antennae orange, but first
   lagellomere brownish black dorsally; 3) wing hyaline except middle and
   basal portions of cell R2+3, cell R4+5 and cell Cu brownish yellow; 4)
   foreleg black; mid and hind coxae, trochanter and femora black, tibiae
   and tarsomeres 1[long dash]4 yellow, tarsomere 5 dark brown. [male].
   Body length 2.04 mm, wing length 2.25 mm. Holotype [male], Liaoning,
   Huanren, Laotu Dingzi Nature Reserve (41.32[degree]N, 124.87[degree]E;
   alt. 1058m), 24 July 2009, collected by WANG Jun-Chao (CAU). Etymology.
   The specific name is derived from the collector's last name "Wang".
C1 Zhang, Jun-Hua; Institute of Plant Quarantine, Chinese Academy of
   Inspection and Quarantine, Beijing 100029, China, China.
EM zjhcome@yahoo.com.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Psilopa leucostoma; Psilopa marginella [China /  / New record;
   systematics] [Nei Mongol /  / ]. 
   Psilopa wangi [Liaoning /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Ephydridae
OR Psilopa - Fallen 1823 (Ephydridae): [Key to species, P. 636]. 
   Psilopa leucostoma - (Meigen 1830) (Ephydridae): [New record]. 
   Psilopa marginella - (Fallen 1823) (Ephydridae): [New record]. 
   Psilopa wangi (Ephydridae): [Sp nov, Liaoning, P. 632].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF RHINGIA FROM CHANGBAI MOUNTAIN, CHINA (DIPTERA,
   SYRPHIDAE).
AU Yuan, Hai-Bin
   Huo, Ke-Ke
   Ren, Bing-Zhong (bzren@163.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 637-639
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper reports a new species of Syrphidae collected from Changbai
   Mountain, Jilin Province, China, Rhingia nigriscutella sp. nov. Type
   specimens are deposited in the Department of Biology, School of Life
   Sciences, Northeast Normal University and the Museum of Animal and
   Botany, Shaanxi University of Technology. Rhingia nigriscutellasp. nov.
   (Figs 1-6) Body length. [male] 10 mm, [female] 10 mm. Wing length.
   [male] 8 mm, [female] 8 mm. Holotype [male], the Valley National Forest
   Park, Linjiang City, Jilin Province
   (41[degree]57[minute]N,126[degree]44[minute]E; alt. 1013m), China, 28
   Aug. 2008, by YUAN Yue. Paratype 1[male], same data as holotype. This
   new species is similar to R. laevigata Loew, but differs in the abdomen.
   The base of tergite 3 of the new species has a pair of nearly
   trapeziform yellow spots, but tergite 3 of Rhingia laevigata is mostly
   brownish red, the rear edge of which is black and the middle with dark
   longitudinal vittae.
C1 Ren, Bing-Zhong; School of Life Sciences, Northeast Normal University,
   Changchun 130024, China, China.
EM bzren@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739

   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Rhingia nigriscutella [Jilin /  / New species].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF TROGLOBITIC LOACH (CYPRINIFORMES, BALITORIDAE),
   TRIPLOPHYSA JIARONGENSIS, FROM GUIZHOU, CHINA.
AU Lin, Yu
   Li, Chao
   Song, Jia-Kun (jksong@shou.edu.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 37
IS 3
PS 640-647
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of troglobitic loach, Triplophysa jiarongensis sp. nov. is
   described based on the collections from Shuijingwan cave
   (25[degrees]28'N, 108[degrees]06'E), Jiarong Town, Libo County, Guizhou
   Province, China. The new species distributes in the Xijiang water system
   such as seven previously known congeneric troglobitic loaches (T.
   aluensis, T. gejiuensis, T. longibarbata, T. macrocephala, T.
   qiubeiensis, T. shilinensis and T. tianeensis). It shares many
   morphological characters with them that associated with subterranean
   environment. This new species can be distinguished from other congeneric
   species by following combination of characters: pectoral fin highly
   developed, reaching the origin of pelvic fin; caudal fin emarginated;
   distal margin of dorsal fin truncate; dorsal-fin origin posterior to
   vertical line of pelvic fin origin; pelvic fin tip reaching beyond anus;
   distal margin of anal fin truncate; adipose-like fin present, along
   dorsal and ventral edge of caudal peduncle; branched rays of dorsal fin
   8; branched rays of anal fin 6; branched rays of pectoral fin 11; total
   vertebra 4+34; pigmentation degenerated; body smooth and scaleless; eyes
   completely degenerated; anterior chamber of air-bladder wrapped in bony
   capsule, posterior chamber of air-bladder well developed. In addition,
   this study introduces the profile of habitat and ecological information
   on the T. jiarongensis.
C1 Song, Jia-Kun; Institute for Marine Biosystem and Neurosciences, College
   of Fisheries and Life Science, Shanghai Ocean University, Shanghai
   201306, China, China.
EM jksong@shou.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Triplophysa jiarongensis [Guizhou /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Balitoridae
OR Triplophysa jiarongensis (Balitoridae): [Sp nov, Guizhou, P. 640]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811075037
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Aphyosemion pseudoelegans (Cyprinodontiformes: Nothobranchiidae), a new
   killifish species from the Cuvette centrale in the Congo Basin
   (Democratic Republic of Congo).
AU Sonnenberg, Rainer (r.sonnenberg.zfmk@uni-bonn.de) 
   Van der Zee, Jouke R.
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 61
IS 1
PS 3-12
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Aphyosemion pseudoelegans, new species, is described, based on
   collections that have been misidentified for decades as A. elegans by
   all authors. The new species superficially resembles A. elegans, but can
   be distinguished from the latter and all other species of the genus by a
   diagnostic combination of colour pattern characters, most prominently it
   has a dark red to black dorsal fin in males, a colour pattern always
   absent in all known A. elegans populations, including the type
   specimens, and an asymmetrical colour pattern on caudal fin margins
   versus symmetrical in A. elegans. Aphyosemion pseudoelegans, new
   species, is found in small rivers on the left bank of the middle Congo,
   where it occurs sympatric and sometimes even syntopic with A. elegans,
   A. sp. aft. castaneum, or an undescribed species of Aphyosemion at
   Ikela.
C1 Sonnenberg, Rainer; Zool Forsch Museum Alexander Koenig, Adenauerallee
   160, Bonn, D-53113, Germany, Germany.
EM r.sonnenberg.zfmk@uni-bonn.de
SC Zoology
SN 2190-7307
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Aphyosemion pseudoelegans [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Aplocheilidae
OR Aphyosemion elegans (Aplocheilidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 6]. 
   Aphyosemion pseudoelegans (Aplocheilidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P.
   5].

DT Article
TI Description of Scriptaphyosemion wieseae (Cyprinodontiformes:
   Nothobranchiidae), a new species from northern Sierra Leone.
AU Sonnenberg, Rainer (r.sonnenberg.zfmk@uni-bonn.de) 
   Busch, Eckhard
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 61
IS 1
PS 13-28
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Scriptaphyosemion wieseae, new species, is described from collections in
   northern Sierra Leone. Results of a small DNA study indicate, that S.
   bertholdi from the southeastern part of the country is the closest
   relative. Both species can be distinguished by male and female color
   pattern and male caudal fin shape.

DT Article
TI New data about some Alticini from Taiwan with descriptions of two new
   species (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae).
AU Nadein, Konstantin (luperus@mail.ru) 
   Lee, Chi-Feng
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 61
IS 1
PS 41-48
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The distributional and taxonomical data on alticine genera Taiwanoliprus
   Komiya, 2006, Pseudoliprus Chujo&Kimoto, 1960, Lipromorpha Chujo&Kimoto,
   1960, and Psylliodes Latreille, 1829 are presented. Psylliodes palleola
   Motschulsky, 1866 and Psylliodes angusticollis Baly, 1874 are
   synonymized with Psylliodes viridana Motschulsky, 1858 based on the
   examination of the type material. The homonymy of Lipromorpha cyanea L.
   Medvedev, 2009 from Laos and Lipromorpha cyanea Chen et Wang, 1980 from
   Yunnan is revealed. Three species Psylliodes subrugosa Jacoby, 1885,
   Psylliodes chujoe Madar, 1960, and Psylliodes cantonensis Gruev, 1981
   are recorded from Taiwan for the first time. Two new species are
   described: Lipromorpha alutacea Nadein, sp. n. and Psylliodes yuae sp.
   n.
C1 Nadein, Konstantin; Natl Acad Sci Ukraine, Dept Gen & Appl Entomol,
   Bogdana Khmelnitskogo St 15, Kiev, UA-01601, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM luperus@mail.ru

SN 2190-7307

   /  / New record].

   47].

   Senior homonym of Lipromorpha cyanea Medvedev 2009, p. 48].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074154
DT Article
TI A revision of East Palaearctic Lobrathium (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Paederinae).
AU Assing, Volker (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 61
IS 1
PS 49-128
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB East Palaearctic species of Lobrathium Mulsant&Rey, 1878, particularly
   those of the Himalaya and China, are revised. Thirty-three species,
   thirty-one of them in Lobrathium and two of lobrathioid habitus in
   Lathrobium Gravenhorst, 1802, are described and illustrated: Lobrathium
   ablectum sp. n (China: Hubei); L. biaculeatum sp. n. (East Nepal); L.
   bicarinatum sp. n. (North India, Nepal); L. bicornutum sp. n. (East
   Nepal); L. bimembre sp. n. (China: Yunnan); L. bispinosum sp. n. (China:
   Guizhou); L. cholaicum sp. n. (China: Tibet); L. configens sp. n.
   (China: Shaanxi, Sichuan, Hubei, Yunnan); L. cornutum sp. n. (East
   Nepal); L. daxuense sp. n. (China: Sichuan); L. demptum sp. n. (China:
   Hubei); L. discrepans sp. n. (North Vietnam); L. domenoides sp. n.
   (China: Sichuan); L. duplex sp. n. (China: Sichuan, Yunnan); L.
   excisissimum sp. n. (Yunnan); L. feldmanni sp. n. (China: Sichuan); L.
   flavipenne sp. n. (North India: Himachal Pradesh); L. integrum sp. n.
   (East Nepal); L. kleebergi sp. n. (Nepal); L. kosiense sp. n. (East
   Nepal); L. lamellatum sp. n. (China: Sichuan); L. mordens sp. n. (North
   India); L. rodeos sp. n. (China: Guizhou); L. retrocarinatum sp. n.
   (China: Yunnan); L. schuelkei sp. n. (China: Shaanxi); L. semiflavum sp.
   n. (Russian Far East); L. sinuatum sp. n. (Central Nepal); L.
   spathulatum sp. n. (China); L. taureum sp. n. (China: Hubei, Beijing);
   L. tuberosum sp. n. (China: Jiangxi); L. unispinosum sp. n. (Nepal);
   Lathrobium lobrathioides sp. n. (China: Sichuan); L. lobrathiforme sp.
   n. (China: Yunnan). All the previously described species from the
   Himalaya and China, except for L. emeiense Zheng, 1988, and some species
   from other East Palaearctic regions are redescribed and illustrated.
   Five new combinations are established: Lobrathium guttula (Fauvel,
   1895), comb. n. (ex Lathrobium); L. pustulatum (Cameron, 1931), comb. n.
   (ex Lathrobium); L. kashmiricum (Cameron, 1931), comb. n. (ex
   Lathrobium); Tetartopeus gracilentus (Kraatz, 1859), comb. n. (ex
   Lathrobium); T. wui (Zheng, 2001), comb. n. (ex Lobrathium). Lathrobium
   sublaeve Motschulsky, 1858 is excluded from both Lathrobium and
   Lobrathium, and treated as Paederini incertae sedis. Lobrathium
   ochreonotatum (Champion, 1922), previously a synonym of L. semicaeruleum
   (Cameron, 1921), is revalidated. Lobratium shibatai varium Ito, 1995 is
   elevated to species rank. Eight synonymies are proposed: Lobrathium
   Mulsant&Rey, 1878 = Ponthrobium Korge, 1971, syn. n.; Lobrathium
   alticola (Cameron, 1943) = L. pirpanjalense Coiffait, 1982, syn. n.; L.
   hongkongense (Bemhauer, 1931) = L. sibynium Zheng, 1988, syn. n., = L.
   ryukyuense Ito, 1996, syn. n.; L. triste (Cameron, 1924) = L.
   kashmiricum (Cameron, 1931, syn. n., = L. afghanicum Coiffait, 1979,
   syn. n., = L. nouristanicum Coiffait, 1979, syn. n.; Tetartopeus wui
   (Zheng, 2001) = T bimaculatum (Li, Tang&Zhu, 2007), syn. n. Lectotypes
   are designated for Lathrobium lederi Eppelsheim, 1884, L. badium
   Cameron, 1924, L. brunneum Cameron, 1931, L. triste Cameron, 1924, L.
   semicaeruleum Cameron, 1921,L. ochreonotatum Champion, 1922, L. guttula
   Fauvel, 1895, L. pustulatum Cameron, 1931, L. cylindricolle Cameron,
   1924, L. hongkongense Bernhauer, 1931, and L. gracilentum Kraatz, 1859.
   Lobrathium, according to currently available evidence a Holarctic genus,
   is now represented in the Palaearctic region by 114 species and one
   subspecies, the vast majority of which, 87 species and one subspecies,
   arc distributed in the East Palaearctic including Middle Asia, Myanmar,
   and North Vietnam. The Himalaya (20 species), China (24 species), Taiwan
   (20 species), and Japan (18 species and one subspecies) are the regions
   with the greatest diversity. Most species, particularly those with
   reduced wings and those subject to wing dimorphisms, appear to have
   remarkably restricted distributions. A catalogue of the Lobrathium
   species recorded from the Palaearctic region and keys to the species of
   the Himalaya and of China are provided. Some species from China and the
   Himalaya are subject to pronounced wing dimorphisms. East Palaearctic
   Lobrathium species are partly found near lakes or on banks of rivers and
   streams, and partly in the leaf litter of forest and shrub habitats at
   altitudes of 450-4400 m. Additional records of several West Palaearctic
   species are reported.
C1 Assing, Volker; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, D-30163, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology

   Staphylinidae

   redescribed and a new combination Geolycosa churitonori (Mcheidze, 1997)

   for the first time. Geolycosa charitonovi is distributed across the

DT Article
TI A new species of Euscorpius Thorell, 1876 (Scorpiones, Euscorpiidae)
   from Italy.
AU Tropea, Gioele
SO Bulletin of the British Arachnological Society
VL 15
IS 8
PS 253-259
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the genus Euscorpius Thorell, 1876 is described based
   on specimens collected at the locality Celano (AQ), Abruzzo, central
   Italy. It is characterized by a peculiar trichobothrial pattern (eba =
   5-5 + eb = 4-4), a large number of pectine teeth, and a general
   colouration which is dark brownish, with legs and telson yellowish. With
   the description of this new species a new trichobothrial pattern is
   described. The number of Euscorpius species in Italy is thus raised to
   ten, and the number of species in the subgenus Euscorpius to five.
SC Zoology
SN 0524-4994

   Eurasia; Europe

DT Article
TI Notes on the distribution of the species of the genus Buthus (Leach,
   1815) (Scorpiones, Buthidae) in Europe, with a description ot a new
   species from Spain.
AU Rossi, Andrea
SO Bulletin of the British Arachnological Society
VL 15
IS 8
PS 273-279
PD July 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of the genus Buthus (Leach, 1815) were described in 2004
   in Spain: B. moutanus Lourengo&Vachon, 2004 and B. ibericus
   Lourenco&Vachon, 2004. Gantenbein&Largiader (2003) distinguished
   divergent clades among European Buthus in their phylogenetic analysis.
   Subsequently, Sousa et al. (2010) reported five distinct mtDNA lineages
   within Buthus from the Iberian Peninsula, two of which they reported for
   the first time. In the present work, a new species, Buthus elongatus n.
   sp., is described, which is most similar to one of the two lineages of
   Sousa et al. (2010): samples Sc 98 and Sc 99, lineage 3 in their study,
   from southern Spain, which resemble Buthus occitanus morphologically,
   but dither from the other specimens of this species by 8.6%. A key for
   all European Buthus and a summary of their distribution are provided.
SC Zoology
SN 0524-4994
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Buthus [Europe /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Buthus elongatus [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Buthus - Leach 1815 (Scorpiones): [Key to species, Europe, P. 278]. 
   Buthus elongatus (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 273].

DT Article
TI A NEW PROTEOCEPHALID TAPEWORM GANGESIA JAYAKWADENSIS FROM CLARIAS
   BATRACHUS AT AURANGABAD (M.S.).
AU Bhavare, V.V. (drbhavarevandana@gmail.com) 
   Shukla, S.J.
SO DAV International Journal of Science
VL 1
IS 2
PS 112-115
PD July 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.davjournal.org/Contents-Issue-2.htm
AW http://www.davjournal.org/DAVIJS-2-28.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Parasites are the major public health problem. It invades man and
   several other domestic animals. Cestode parasites are the intestinal
   parasites found in various animals like fish, sheep, goat, poultry etc.
   Four specimens, of the cestode parasites were collected from the
   intestine of a freshwater fish Clarias batrachus from Jayakwadi project
   at Paithan, Dist. Aurangabad. A new species of cestode parasite,
   Gangasia jayakwadensis n.sp. has been described in this paper. It is
   differentiated from all known species of the genus in scolex large,
   quadrangular, rostellum armed with a double circle of hooks, one circle
   with 25 hooks, second circle with 29 hooks, mature proglottids squarish
   in shape, broader than long, testes 300 to 310 (305), ovary is large in
   size, distinctly bilobed. The vitellaria are follicular; uterus is
   tubular in mature segment. The gravid segments are large, slightly
   longer than broad. The eggs are medium, oval and operculated.

   India.

PT J

PM 22497860
DT Article
TI The correlation between tick (Ixodes persulcatus Sch.) questing
   behaviour and synganglion neuronal responses to odours.
AU Romashchenko, A.V. (yuter2006@yandex.ru) 
   Ratushnyak, A.S.
   Zapara, T.A.
   Tkachev, S.E.
   Moshkin, M.P.
SO Journal of Insect Physiology
VL 58
IS 7
PS 903-910
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 25
AB We examined the behavioural and electrophysiological responses of taiga
   ticks (Ixodes persulcatus) to several olfactory stimuli:
   osmopherone[registered trademark] (5-a-androst-16-en-3-ol),
   Osmopherine[registered trademark] (butanoic and 3-methylbutanoic acids),
   DEET[registered trademark] (N,N-diethyl-meta-toluamide), ethanol (96%),
   and water (control stimulus). To study individual tick behavioural
   reactions to these stimuli, we used a Y-shaped glass maze (n = 50). To
   study the electrophysiological reactions of the ticks' synganglia to
   these olfactory stimuli, we recorded the shifts of total potential (TP)
   of pre-oesophageal neurons in response to odour stimulation of Hailer's
   organ (n = 25). We found that Osmopherine[registered trademark]
   attracted ticks and frequently evoked negative shifts of TP, whereas the
   response to Osmopherone[registered trademark] did not differ from the
   reaction to water. DEET[registered trademark] and ethanol acted as tick
   repellents and generally evoked positive shifts of TP. We also tested
   each tick for its questing height (QH) on a glass rod that was at an
   incline of 75[degree], and we tested for the presence of pathogens i.e.,
   DNA of Borrelia burgdorferi sp. s.l. and RNA of tick-borne encephalitis
   virus (TBEV). The degree of response to Osmopherine[registered
   trademark] positively correlated with the QH. The ticks with the highest
   values of QH showed a greater prevalence of the tick-borne pathogen
   Borrelia sp. s.l. compared with the ticks that did not reach the maximum
   QH. The present results show a correlation between the
   electrophysiological reaction of the synganglia of ticks and their
   behavioural responses to different odours. (C) 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Romashchenko, A.V.; Acad Lavrentev Ave 10, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia,
   Russia.
EM yuter2006@yandex.ru
RI Tkachev, Sergey/I-7390-2013; Moshkin, Mikhail P./N-7620-2014
OI Tkachev, Sergey/0000-0001-7767-380X
SC Neurosciences &Neurology; Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 0022-1910
BD Nervous system; Sensory reception; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Abiotic factors; Chemical factors
DE Ixodes persulcatus [Ganglia / Synganglion neuronal responses /
   Electrophysiology] [Chemoreception / Olfaction / ] [Hosts / Host seeking
   / ] [Gases / Odours / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Ixodes persulcatus (Acari): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI Naphthalenones from a Perenniporia sp Inhabiting the Larva of a
   Phytophagous Weevil, Euops chinesis.
AU Feng, Yu
   Wang, Lin
   Niu, Shubin
   Li, Li
   Si, Yikang
   Liu, Xingzhong (liuxz@im.ac.cn) 
   Che, Yongsheng
SO Journal of Natural Products
VL 75
IS 7
PS 1339-1345
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 40
AB The new naphthalenone derivatives perenniporides A-D (1-4) were isolated
   from solid cultures of a fungus Perenniporia sp. inhabiting the larva of
   Euops chinesis, a phytophagous weevil with high host specificity to the
   medicinal plant Fallopia japonica. The structures of 1-4 were elucidated
   primarily by NMR experiments, and 1 was confirmed by X-ray
   crystallography. The absolute configuration of 1 and 2 was assigned by
   electronic circular dichroism (ECD) calculations, whereas that of the
   C-10 tertiary alcohol in 3 was deduced via the CD data of the in situ
   formed (Rh2(OCOCF3)4) complex and supported by the ECD data Compound 1
   showed antifungal activity against five plant pathogens.

TI EARLY ORDOVICIAN MITRATES AND A POSSIBLE SOLUTE (ECHINODERMATA) FROM THE
   WESTERN UNITED STATES.
AU Sumrall, Colin D. (csumrall@utk.edu) 
   Sprinkle, James
   Guensburg, Thomas E.
   Dattilo, Benjamin F.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 595-604
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new kirkocystid mitrate stylophorans (Echinodermata, Homalozoa) and
   a new possible solute (Echinodermata, Homalozoa) are described from the
   Early Ordovician of the western United States. The mitrates are among
   the earliest members of their clade to appear near the beginning of the
   Ordovician Radiation. Anatifopsis ninemilensis new species comes from
   the Ninemile Shale in central Nevada and the McKelligon Canyon Formation
   in west Texas. Anatifopsis fillmorensis new species comes from the
   middle Fillmore Formation in western Utah and a Ninemile Shale
   equivalent limestone bed in southern Nevada. The possible solute
   Drepanocystis dubius new genus new species from the lower Wah Wah
   Limestone in western Utah, shows unusual morphology with an elongate
   theca and a long arm shaped like a sickle.

DT Article
TI PODOCALLICHIRUS LAEPAENSIS, A NEW GHOST SHRIMP (CRUSTACEA, DECAPODA,
   CALLIANASSIDAE) FROM THE LATE MIOCENE OF SOUTHWEST SPAIN.
AU Hyzny, Matus (hyzny.matus@gmail.com) 
   Muniz, Fernando
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 616-625
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Callianassids are among the most commonly found decapod crustacean
   fossils but their generic assignment is often difficult. Numerous
   cheliped remains have been found in the upper Miocene deposits of
   southwest Spain allowing description of a new species of a ghost shrimp,
   Podocallichirus laepaensis. The assignment of the new form to the
   respective genus is based mainly on the morphology of the major cheliped
   merus and provides useful implications for paleontological studies.
   Podocallichirus laepaensis is the first fossil record of the genus known
   to date. Several specimens preserved in association with and within
   Ophiomorpha traces are interpreted as in situ preservation. Thus, the
   new ghost shrimp is identified as the producer of trace fossils.
C1 Hyzny, Matus; Comenius Univ, Fac Nat Sci, Mlynska Dolina G1, Bratislava,
   84215, Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM hyzny.matus@gmail.com

SN 0022-3360

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Podocallichirus [Spain /  / new record] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Podocallichirus laepaensis [Spain /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI OCCURRENCE OF THE ISOPOD ARCHAEONISCUS COREAENSIS NEW SPECIES FROM THE
   LOWER CRETACEOUS JINJU FORMATION, KOREA.
AU Park, Tae-Yoon (taeyoon.park@hotmail.com) 
   Wilson, George D.F.
   Lee, Dong-Chan
   Choi, Duck K.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 626-640
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The fossil isopod crustacean genus Archaeoniscus has been known to occur
   in England, France and Germany during the Upper Jurassic, and in Mexico
   and Egypt during the Lower Cretaceous. The morphology of this genus is
   unique in having dorsoventrally compressed body, the cephalon set deeply
   into the first pereionite, pleon as wide as pereion, and a broad
   semicircular pleotelson. These features have resulted in placing the
   classification of the genus in the monotypic family Archaeoniscidae.
   However, due to the lack of detailed morphological data, suprafamilial
   classification of this genus has remained unclear, as well as its
   ecology and lifestyle. Here we report Archaeoniscus coreaensis n. sp.
   from the Jinju Formation, Gyeongsang Basin, Korea. The occurrence of
   Archaeoniscus in the East Asia implies that the genus may have had a
   worldwide distribution. The Gyeongsang Basin was a Cretaceous backarc
   basin, which consists of exclusively non-marine sedimentary sequences.
   The occurrence of this genus, therefore, indicates that Archaeoniscus
   successfully adapted to a freshwater ecosystem as well. Detailed anatomy
   including antennulae, antennae, pereiopods, and uropods was observed
   from well-preserved multiple specimens, which allows better
   understanding of the morphology of Archaeoniscus. The axial structure in
   the posterior part of the body, which was previously interpreted as a
   unique brood pouch characterizing the family, turned out to be a remnant
   of the hindgut. Females of all isopods and most of the members of the
   superorder Peracarida have a thoracic ventral brood pouch, modified from
   the thoracic coxal endites. Based on the morphology of the largely
   unmodified ambulatory pereiopods of A. coreaensis, the possibility of
   Archaeoniseus being ectoparasitic is discounted. Instead, the flattened
   body and the form of limbs of A. coreaensis would have been suitable for
   a benthic lifestyle.
C1 Park, Tae-Yoon; Korea Polar Res Inst, Div Polar Earth Syst Sci, Incheon,
   406840, South Korea, South Korea.
EM taeyoon.park@hotmail.com
OI Choi, Duck/0000-0002-5589-537X
SC Zoology
SN 0022-3360
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Archaeoniscus coreaensis [South Korea /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Archaeoniscus - Milne-Edwards 1843 (Isopoda): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   628; Fossil]. 
   Archaeoniscus coreaensis (Isopoda): [Sp nov, South Korea, Cretaceous, P.
   631; Fossil]. 
DI 10.1666/11-131R.1
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811073831
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14811073832
DT Article
TI CALOSARGUS TALBRAGARENSIS NEW SPECIES: THE FIRST BRACHYCERAN FLY FROM
   THE JURASSIC OF AUSTRALIA (DIPTERA, ARCHISARGIDAE).
AU Oberprieler, Stefanie K. (stef_oberprieler@hotmail.com) 
   Yeates, David K.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 641-645
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The first fly fossil discovered from the Upper Jurassic Talbragar Fish
   Bed in Australia is described and illustrated. Based on a single, well
   preserved wing, Calosargus (Calosargus) talbragarensis new species is
   assigned to the extinct brachyceran family Archisargidae. Wing
   morphology suggests a relationship between this extinct family and
   Stratiomyidae. The Archisargidae have so far only been found in China,
   Kazakhstan and Mongolia. Calosargus Mostovski, 1997 currently comprises
   seven species from the Callovian (late Middle Jurassic) of China and
   three species from the Oxfordian (early Upper Jurassic) of Kazakhstan.
   This oldest brachyceran fossil from Australia and first record of the
   Archisargidae in the southern hemisphere presents evidence that higher
   flies were present in this region in the Jurassic, when this group is
   thought to have commenced its diversification.
C1 Oberprieler, Stefanie K.; Australian Natl Univ, Res Sch Biol, Canberra,
   ACT, 2601, Australia, Australia.

   Oberprieler, Stefanie K/B-4031-2015
OI Yeates, David K/0000-0001-7729-6143; Oberprieler,
   Stefanie/0000-0002-1967-3489;

DT Article
TI A CONCH WITH A COLLAR: EARLY ONTOGENY OF THE ENIGMATIC FOSSIL BIVALVE
   MYOCONCHA.
AU Kaim, Andrzej (kaim@twarda.pan.pl) 
   Schneider, Simon
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 652-658
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Larval and juvenile growth stages of myoconchid bivalves (family
   Kalenteridae) are illustrated and described for the first time.
   Excellently preserved shells of Myoconcha crassa J. Sowerby, 1824 from
   the middle Bathonian (Middle Jurassic) clay/silt deposits of southern
   Poland reveal that the prodissoconch in this taxon is large (exceeding
   350 [mu]m in length) and characterized by a prominent, collar-like
   structure arising from the demarcation to the dissoconch. Similar
   prodissoconch morphology has not been described previously in any other
   bivalve genus. The large size and absence of a prodissoconch II strongly
   suggest a non-planktotrophic development of the larvae, indicating
   either simple lecithotrophy or long-term brooding and parental care for
   the larvae in this species. Consequently, the new discovery constitutes
   the earliest well-documented record of non-planktotrophic development in
   the Bivalvia. The shell of Myoconcha crassa is composed of an outer
   cross-lamellar layer and an inner complex cross-lamellar layer. This
   composition suggests that the Kalenteridae may be included in the
   Carditida rather than the Palaeoheterodonta or Anomalodesmata. The genus
   Pseudomyoconcha Rossi Ronchetti and Allasinaz, 1966 is rejected herein
   and considered as a junior synonym of Myoconcha J. Sowerby, 1824.

   PL-00818, Poland, Poland.
EM kaim@twarda.pan.pl

DT Article
TI TAXONOMY, ONTOGENY AND PALEOECOLOGY OF TWO SPECIES OF HARBINIA TSAO,
   1959 (CRUSTACEA, OSTRACODA) FROM THE SANTANA FORMATION, LOWER
   CRETACEOUS, NORTHEASTERN BRAZIL.
AU Antonietto, Lucas Silveira (antoniettols@gmail.com) 
   Gobbo, Silvia Regina
   Do Carmo, Dermeval Aparecido
   Assine, Mario Luiz
   Castanheira Cordeiro Fernandes, Maria Alice Morgado
   Silva, Jose Eduardo Lima E.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 659-668
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The Araripe Basin is the most extensive interior basin in northeastern
   Brazil, comprising areas of Ceara, Piaui and Pernambuco states. The
   Santana Formation, attributed to the Aptian-?lower Albian age of the
   basin, is subdivided into two members, Crato and Romualdo, which bear an
   abundant fossil record of plant fragments, arthropods and vertebrates,
   especially 3D-preserved fishes. The present study focuses on the
   taxonomy, ontogeny and paleoecology of two ostracode species from the
   Romualdo Member and the top section of the Crato Member (Ipubi layers),
   Harbinia salitrensis (Krommelbein and Weber, 1971) emend. and H. alta
   new species. The ontogenetic series for both species are illustrated,
   except for the A-8 instar; H. salitrensis is also redescribed. The
   present work is also the first to produce quantitative information about
   the paleoecology of the Santana Formation based on ostracode
   populations. The results obtained from analyses of the population
   age-structure of both species, in addition to dominance (Simpson) and
   diversity index (Shannon) values, corroborated previous data on the
   studied sequence. According to these results, the strata were deposited
   in a limnic, low-to-moderate energy environment with salinity levels
   varying from oligohaline to mesohaline. The new data indicate the
   possibility of these environments also being hypersaline.

DT Article
TI NEW BOTHREMYDID TURTLE (TESTUDINES, PLEURODIRA) FROM THE PALEOCENE OF
   NORTHEASTERN COLOMBIA.
AU Cadena, Edwin A. (eacadena@ncsu.edu) 
   Bloch, Jonathan I.
   Jaramillo, Carlos A.
SO Journal of Paleontology
VL 86
IS 4
PS 688-698
PD Jul 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new turtle, Puentemys mushaisaensis, from the middle to late Paleocene
   Cerrejon Formation of Colombia, is described on the basis of a partial
   skull and many partial to nearly complete carapaces and plastrons
   representing multiple ontogenetic stages. Whereas P. mushaisaensis is
   unique in aspects of its shell morphology, it shares many diagnostic
   characteristics of bothremydid pleurodirans, including a long
   exoccipital-quadrate contact, a very low and rounded almost circular
   carapace, and a thinner internal bone cortex than that of the external
   cortex in both the carapace and plastron. With a maximum carapacial
   length of 151 cm, P. mushaisaensis is the largest known bothremydid
   turtle and represents the First occurrence of bothremydids in the
   Paleogene of South American tropics. Results from a cladistic analysis
   of bothremydids indicate that P. mushaisaensis shares a close
   relationship with Foxemys mechinorum from the Late Cretaceous of Europe,
   indicating a wide-spread geographical distribution for bothremydines
   during the Late Cretaceous Paleocene.
