PM 22726496
DT Article
TI The complete mitochondrial genomes of two ghost moths, Thitarodes
   renzhiensis and Thitarodes yunnanensis: the ancestral gene arrangement
   in Lepidoptera.
AU Cao, Yong-Qiang (yangdr@xtbg.ac.cn) 
   Chuan Ma
   Chen, Ji-Yue
   Yang, Da-Rong
SO BMC Genomics
VL 13
SU Article No 276
PS 13pp.
PD 22 June 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.biomedcentral.com/bmcgenomics
AW http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1471-2164-13-276.pdf
NT Unpaginated.
LA English
U1 3
U2 33
AB Background: Lepidoptera encompasses more than 160,000 described species
   that have been classified into 45-48 superfamilies. The previously
   determined Lepidoptera mitochondrial genomes (mitogenomes) are limited
   to six superfamilies of the lineage Ditrysia. Compared with the
   ancestral insect gene order, these mitogenomes all contain a tRNA
   rearrangement. To gain new insights into Lepidoptera mitogenome
   evolution, we sequenced the mitogenomes of two ghost moths that belong
   to the non-ditrysian lineage Hepialoidea and conducted a comparative
   mitogenomic analysis across Lepidoptera. Results: The mitogenomes of
   Thitarodes renzhiensis and T. yunnanensis are 16,173 bp and 15,816 bp
   long with an A + T content of 81.28 % and 82.34 %, respectively. Both
   mitogenomes include 13 protein-coding genes, 22 transfer RNA genes, 2
   ribosomal RNA genes, and the A + T-rich region. Different tandem repeats
   in the A + T-rich region mainly account for the size difference between
   the two mitogenomes. All the protein-coding genes start with typical
   mitochondrial initiation codons, except for cox1 (CGA) and nad1 (TTG) in
   both mitogenomes. The anticodon of trnS(AGN) in T. renzhiensis and T.
   yunnanensis is UCU instead of the mostly used GCU in other sequenced
   Lepidoptera mitogenomes. The 1,584-bp sequence from rrnS to nad2 was
   also determined for an unspecified ghost moth (Thitarodes sp.), which
   has no repetitive sequence in the A + T-rich region. All three
   Thitarodes species possess the ancestral gene order with trnI-trnQ-trnM
   located between the A + T-rich region and nad2, which is different from
   the gene order trnM-trnI-trnQ in all previously sequenced Lepidoptera
   species. The formerly identified conserved elements of Lepidoptera
   mitogenomes (i.e. the motif 'ATAGA' and poly-T stretch in the A + T-rich
   region and the long intergenic spacer upstream of nad2) are absent in
   the Thitarodes mitogenomes. Conclusion: The mitogenomes of T.
   renzhiensis and T. yunnanensis exhibit unusual features compared with
   the previously determined Lepidoptera mitogenomes. Their ancestral gene
   order indicates that the tRNA rearrangement event(s) likely occurred
   after Hepialoidea diverged from other lepidopteran lineages.
   Characterization of the two ghost moth mitogenomes has enriched our
   knowledge of Lepidoptera mitogenomes and contributed to our
   understanding of the mechanisms underlying mitogenome evolution,
   especially gene rearrangements.
C1 Cao, Yong-Qiang; Key Laboratory of Tropical Forest Ecology,
   Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
   Kunming 650223, China, China.
EM yangdr@xtbg.ac.cn
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1471-2164
BD Genetics; Evolution
DE Lepidoptera [Molecular genetics / Ancestral gene arrangement / New
   insights] [Evolution /  / ]. 
   Thitarodes renzhiensis; Thitarodes yunnanensis [Molecular genetics /
   Complete mitochondrial genome sequences / ] [Evolution / Ordinal-level
   ancestral gene arrangement reconstructions / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Exoporia,
   Hepialoidea, Hepialidae
OR Lepidoptera (Insecta). 
   Thitarodes renzhiensis (Hepialidae). 
   Thitarodes yunnanensis (Hepialidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14902010778
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14809063105
DT Article
TI Notes on the genera Manodirphia gen. nov. and Lemaireodirphia gen. nov.,
   with descriptions of ten new species (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Einige Anmerkungen zu den Gattungen Manodirphia gen. nov. and
   Lemaireodirphia gen. nov. mit Beschreibungen neuer Taxa (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 5
IS 2
PS 26-43
PD 22 June 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new genera, Manodirphia gen. nov. (type species: Ormiscodes manes
   DRUCE, 1897) and Lemaireodirphia gen. nov. (type species: Dirphia hoegei
   DRUCE, 1886) are erected. Furthermore, ten new species in
   Lemaireodirphia gen. nov. from Mexico are described and figured: L.
   oaxacana sp. n. (Mexico: Oaxaca), L. guerreroiana sp. n. (Mexico:
   Guerrero), L. centralis sp. n. (Mexico: Oaxaca), L. albida sp. n.
   (Mexico: Oaxaca), L. rubra sp. n. (Mexico: Oaxaca), L. rosivora sp. n.
   (Mexico: Oaxaca), L., fusca sp. n. (Mexico: Oaxaca), L. knorkei sp. n.
   (Mexico: Durango), L. chiapasiana sp. n. (Mexico: Chiapas) and L.
   transversaria sp. n. (Mexico: Oaxaca). All holotypes (ex coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), or Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau (CFMP)) are in
   CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with
   this collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen,
   Munich, Germany.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

AB Three new species of the genus Prohylesia DRAUDT, 1929 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed by the type
   locality in the format: country (province/department/state)): P.
   carpishiana sp. n. (Peru (Huanuco)), P. bahikani sp. n. (Brazil (Bahia))
   and P. bahiana sp. n. (Brazil (Bahia)). The holotype [female] of P.
   carpishiana sp. n. is deposited in coll. Ronald Brechlin, Pasewalk
   (CRBP), in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together
   with this collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung
   Munchen, Munich, Germany. The holotype a'c of P. bahikani sp. n. and P.
   bahiana sp. n. (ex coll. Carlos G. C. MrELIa, Brazil (CGCM)) are
   deposited in coll. Pe. Jesus S. MOURE, Departamento de Zoologia,
   Universidade Federal do Parana, Curitiba, Parana, Brazil (DZUP).

DT Article
TI Ulopsina, a remarkable new ulopine leafhopper genus from China.
AU Dai, Wu
   Viraktamath, Chandra A.
   Zhang, Yalin (yalinzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
SO Journal of Insect Science (Tucson)
VL 12
SU Article 70
PS 1-9
PD 22 June 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.insectscience.org/12.70/i1536-2442-12-70.pdf
AW http://www.insectscience.org/12.70/i1536-2442-12-70.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An unusual new cicadellid genus, Ulopsina gen. nov. and two new species,
   U. sinica sp. nov. and U. szwedoi sp. nov. from China are described,
   illustrated, and placed in the subfamily Ulopinae. The genus has
   characters of both the tribes Mesargini and Coloborrhinini, suggesting
   that the delimitation of these tribes may not be natural. The tribal
   placement of Ulopsina is uncertain. A checklist of the subfamily
   Ulopinae from China is also provided, and nine Chinese species
   designated under the genus Moonia are herein transferred to Mesargus,
   namely Mesargus albomaculata (Li) comb. nov., M. brevita (Cai et Shen)
   comb. nov., M. castanea (Kuoh) comb. nov., M. hei (Cai et Shen) comb.
   nov., M. hirsuta (Li) comb. nov., M. hyboma (Cai et Kuoh) comb. nov., M.
   maculigena (Kuoh) comb. nov., M. serrata (Li and Zhang) comb. nov., and
   M. spinapenis (Li and Zhang) comb. nov.
C1 Zhang, Yalin; Key Laboratory of Plant Protection Resources and Pest
   Management, Ministry of Education, Entomological Museum, Northwest A&F
   University, Yangling, Shaanxi 712100, China, China.
EM yalinzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn

PT J
AN ZOOR14808055865
PM 22357266
DT Article
TI Discovery of a new family of amphibians from northeast India with
   ancient links to Africa.
AU Kamei, Rachunliu G.
   San Mauro, Diego
   Gower, David J.
   Van Bocxlaer, Ines
   Sherratt, Emma
   Thomas, Ashish
   Babu, Suresh
   Bossuyt, Franky
   Wilkinson, Mark
   Biju, S.D. (sdbiju@cemde.du.ac.in) 
SO Proceedings of the Royal Society Biological Sciences Series B
VL 279
IS 1737
PS 2396-2401
PD Jun 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 38
AB The limbless, primarily soil-dwelling and tropical caecilian amphibians
   (Gymnophiona) comprise the least known order of tetrapods. On the basis
   of unprecedented extensive fieldwork, we report the discovery of a
   previously overlooked, ancient lineage and radiation of caecilians from
   threatened habitats in the underex-plored states of northeast India.
   Molecular phylogenetic analyses of mitogenomic and nuclear DNA
   sequences, and comparative cranial anatomy indicate an unexpected
   sister-group relationship with the exclusively African family
   Herpelidae. Relaxed molecular clock analyses indicate that these
   lineages diverged in the Early Cretaceous, about 140 Ma. The discovery
   adds a major branch to the amphibian tree of life and sheds light on
   both the evolution and biogeography of caecilians and the biotic history
   of northeast India-an area generally interpreted as a gateway between
   biodiversity hotspots rather than a distinct biogeographic unit with its
   own ancient endemics. Because of its distinctive morphology, inferred
   age and phylogenetic relationships, we recognize the newly discovered
   caecilian radiation as a new family of modern amphibians.
C1 Biju, S.D.; Univ Delhi, Ctr Environm Management Degraded Ecosyst, Delhi,
   110007, India, India.
EM sdbiju@cemde.du.ac.in
RI Sherratt, Emma/A-9931-2011; Van Bocxlaer, Ines/L-4852-2015; San Mauro,
   Diego/E-7996-2012; Wilkinson, Mark/J-2026-2014
OI Sherratt, Emma/0000-0003-2164-7877; San Mauro,
   Diego/0000-0002-2214-1125; Wilkinson, Mark/0000-0002-9459-8976; Babu,
   Suresh/0000-0002-3004-3066
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0962-8452
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Gymnophiona [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / Systematics] [Zoogeography / 
   / ] [India / Northeast / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Gymnophiona,
   Caeciliidae
OR Gymnophiona (Lissamphibia). 
   Chikila (Gymnophiona): [Gen nov, Of new family Chikilidae, Type species
   Herpele fulleri Alcock 1904, p. 2398].

   from Herpele, p. 2398].

   p. 2398].

PT J
AN ZOOR14808058504
DT Article
TI Revision and phylogenetic analysis of the Papuan weevil genus Thyestetha
   Pascoe (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Cryptorhynchinae).
AU Eberle, Jonas
   Taenzler, Rene
   Riedel, Alexander (riedel@smnk.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3355
PS 1-28
PD 22 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3355.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3355.html
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Thyestetha Pascoe, an apterous genus of Papuan Cryptorhynchinae is
   revised. It contains two previously described species, T. carbonaria
   Faust and T. nitida Pascoe, plus seven new species: T. discolor sp. n.,
   T. emarginata sp. n., T. glabra sp. n., T. lubrica sp. n., T. oblita sp.
   n., T. puncticollis sp. n., and T. splendens sp. n.. Lectotypes are
   designated for T. carbonaria, T. nitida, and Pantoxistus rubripennis
   Chevrolat which is a junior synonym of T. nitida (syn. n.). The genus
   and its species are described and the characters relevant for their
   identification are illustrated. A key to the species is provided.
   Phylogenetic analyses are performed, utilizing molecular and
   morphological approaches. A maximum likelihood tree including 5
   Thyestetha species and 2 outgroups is presented, based on 3
   mitochondrial and 4 nuclear markers. A maximum parsimony analysis of 19
   morphological characters includes all described species. Thyestetha is
   presumably closely related to Telaugia Pascoe and Elichora Pascoe. The
   group is restricted to New Guinea and some smaller neighboring islands.
C1 Riedel, Alexander; Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde, Erbprinzenstr.
   13, D-76133 Karlsruhe, Germany, Germany.
EM riedel@smnk.de

   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia

   [Papua New Guinea /  / ].

   Curculionidae

DT Article
TI A brachypterous Bryophaenocladius (Diptera: Chironomidae:
   Orthocladiinae) with hypopygium inversum from Heggie's Rock, Georgia,
   U.S.A.
AU Epler, J.H. (johnepler3@comcast.net) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3355
PS 51-61
PD 22 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3355.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03355p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The adult male and female, pupa and larva of a new species,
   Bryophaenocladius chrissichuckorum, are described from Heggie's Rock,
   Georgia, U.S.A. Males and females of the species are brachypterous;
   males have a hypopygium inversum. Pupae differ from other described
   Bryophaenocladius by the presence of three pairs of small setae on the
   prefrons. Larvae have a mentum with 2 broad median teeth and AR of about
   0.99, but are not realistically separable from many other Bry-
   ophaenocladius species. The immature stages inhabit shallow ephemeral
   pools.
C1 Epler, J.H.; 461 Tiger Hammnock Road, Crawfordville, FL 32327, USA, USA.
EM johnepler3@comcast.net
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Entomology

   Body form; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   ] [Georgia-USA / Columbia County, Heggie's Rock Preserve / ]. 
   Bryophaenocladius chrissichuckorum [Georgia-USA /  / New species].

   Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae).

U1 0
U2 0
AB The monotypic genus Ceroderma Raffray and the type species C. asperata
   Raffray are redescribed and illustrated, based on examination of the
   holotype and additional specimens collected near the type locality. An
   allied new genus and species, Cerochusa cilioceps Yin&Nomura, gen. et
   sp. nov. is described from Hainan Island, South China, and distinguished
   from related batrisine genera.

TI Twelve new taxa in the genus Copaxa Walker, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Zwoelf neue Taxa der Gattung Copaxa Walker, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 5
IS 2
PS 5-25
PD 22 June 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twelve new taxa in the genus Copaxa WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed by the type
   locality in the format: country (province/department/state)): C.
   andescens sp. n. (Bolivia (Cochabamba)), C. knorkei sp. n. (Mexico
   (Chiapas)), C. mexcentralis sp. n. (Mexico (Mexico)), C. siriae sp. n.
   (Mexico (Durango)), C. yungallita sp. n. (Bolivia (La Paz)), C.
   amazpandens sp. n. (Peru (Amazonas)), C. andorientalis sp. n. (Peru
   (Cajamarca)), C. corralesi sp. n. (Peru (Cajamarca)), C. orientalis
   guamaniana ssp. n. (Peru (Piura)), C. chimaltenangensis sp. n.
   (Guatemala (Chimaltenango)), C. sanmarcosiana sp. n. (Guatemala (San
   Marcos)) and C. purulhensis sp. n. (Guatemala (Baja Verapaz)). All
   holotypes (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), or Frank MEISTER,
   Prenzlau (CFMP)) are in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen, Munich, Germany. Furthermore C.
   niepelti DRAUDT, 1929 stat. nov. is removed from synonymy with C.
   decrescens WALKER 1855 and treated as a full species. In addition C.
   ignescens LEMAIRE, 1978 syn. nov. is recognized as a junior synonym of
   C. niepelti stat. nov. Finally, a neotype is designated for Copaxa rufa
   DRAUDT, 1929 (stat. nov.?, syn. rev.?) (deposited in Zoologische
   Staatssanunlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany). C. brunneocaeca LEMAIRE,
   1982 stat. nov., hitherto treated as a subspecies of C. expandens
   WALKER, 1855, is raised to full species status.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

TI Three new species in the genus Leucanella Lemaire, 1969 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Drei neue Arten der Gattung Leucanella Lemaire, 1969 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 5
IS 2
PS 44-49
PD 22 June 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the genus Leucanella LEMAIRE, 1969 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured (names are followed by the type
   locality in the format: country (province/department/state)): L.
   neglecta sp. n. (Peru (Junin)), L. arcuata sp. n. (Peru (Cajamarca)) and
   L. verdiana sp. n. (Peru (Amazonas)). All holotypes are deposited in
   coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll. Museum WITT, Munich
   (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will be included
   in Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen, Munich, Germany.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

DT Article
TI New European bee species of the tribe Osmiini (Hymenoptera: Apoidea:
   Megachilidae).
AU Muller, Andreas (andreas.mueller@ipw.agrl.ethz.ch) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3355
PS 29-50
PD 22 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3355.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03355p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Bees of the tribe Osmiini (Megachilidae) are represented by about 230
   described species in Europe. In this publication, 15 new European
   osmiine bee species are described and diagnosed: Hoplitis (Alcidamea)
   occidentalis spec. nov., Hoplitis (Anthocopa) peniculifera spec. nov.,
   Hoplitis (Hoplitis) hilbera spec. nov., Hoplitis (Hoplitis) lithodorae
   spec. nov. and Hoplitis manuelae spec. nov. from Spain; Chelostoma
   (Chelostoma) siciliae spec. nov. from Sicily; Chelostoma (Foveosmia)
   incognitum spec. nov., Chelostoma (Foveosmia) longifacies spec. nov.,
   Chelostoma (Gyrodromella) aegaeicum spec. nov., Hoplitis (Annosmia)
   monticola spec. nov., Hoplitis (Anthocopa) nicolaei spec. nov., Hoplitis
   (Anthocopa) serainae spec. nov. and Protosmia (Nano- smia) montana spec.
   nov. from Greece; Chelostoma (Chelostoma) comosum spec. nov. from
   Cyprus; and Hoplitis (Anthocopa) caucasicola spec. nov. from the
   Caucasus.

   Switzerland.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Fijian Chimarra (Trichoptera, Philopotamidae) with
   description of 24 new species.
AU Johanson, Kjell Arne (kjell.arne.johanson@nrm.se) 
   Olah, Janos
SO Zootaxa
VL 3354
PS 1-58
PD 21 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3354.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03354p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The philopotamid genus Chimarra (Trichoptera) of Fiji is revised. The
   previously described species Chimarra nervosa (Brauer, 1867) is
   considered a nomen dubium. Chimarra indigota Mosely, 1941, is
   synonymized with Chimarra manni Banks, 1924. The following 24 new
   Chimarra species are described: C. vanuensis, C. macuatensis, C.
   schlingeri, C. nath- ani, C. braueri, C. vitiensis, C. karoyanitensis,
   C. tokotaai, C. vuda, C. naitasirensis, C. veisarensis, C. fijiana, C.
   abacensis, C. cakaudrovensis, C. cartwrighti, C. kimminsi, C.
   kadavuensis, C. lavensis, C. devoensis, C. helomyzida, C. tipulida, C.
   psychodida, C. levuensis, and C. malickyi. Chimarra signata Banks, 1936,
   C. manni Banks, 1924, and C. obscurella Banks, 1924, are re-described
   based on type material.
C1 Johanson, Kjell Arne; Swedish Museum of Natural History, Entomology
   Department, Box 50007, 10405 Stockholm, Sweden, Sweden.
EM kjell.arne.johanson@nrm.se
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oceanic islands;
   Pacific Ocean islands

   vanuensis; Chimarra veisarensis; Chimarra vitiensis; Chimarra vuda [Fiji
   /  / New species]. 
   Philopotamidae [Fiji /  / Key to genera & species]. 
   Trichoptera [Fiji /  / Key to families].

TI Two new species of Paravelia Breddin, 1898 and distributional notes
   concerning the Veliidae from Minas Gerais State, Brazil (Insecta:
   Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Gerromorpha).
AU Figueiredo Moreira, Felipe Ferraz (felipento@hotmail.com) 
   Freires Barbosa, Julianna
SO Zootaxa
VL 3354
PS 58-68
PD 21 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3354.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03354p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paravelia lanemeloi sp. nov. and P. nieseri sp. nov. are described.
   Microvelia inannana, Oiovelia brasiliensis, Rhagovelia modesta, R.
   novana, R. sooretama, R. teresa, R. vaniniae, and R. zela are recorded
   for the first time from Minas Gerais State. Additional records are
   presented for M. longipes, M. pulchella, R. aiuruoca, R. hambletoni, R.
   macta, R. robusta, R. sabrina, R. triangula, R. trianguloides, and R.
   turmalis.

DT Article
TI Revision of the type series of Empis (Planempis) mandarina Frey, the
   type species of Planempis (Diptera: Empididae).
AU Saigusa, Toyohei (toyohei_saigusa@yahoo.co.jp) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3353
PS 55-68
PD 21 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3353.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03353p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The type series of Empis (Planempis) mandarina Frey, 1953, the type
   species of Planempis Frey, from Fukien (Fujian), China and Kambaiti,
   Myanmar is revised and found to include four species. The lectotype is
   designated for a Fukien male specimen. Two other species, E. (Planempis)
   lindebergi sp. nov. and E. (Planempis) janssoni sp. nov. are described
   based on a male syn- type, and a male and three female syntypes from
   Kambaiti, respectively. A species represented by females from Fukien is
   not conspecific with any of these species and remains unnamed.
C1 Saigusa, Toyohei; 7-1-402 Baikoen 2-chome, Chuo-ku, Fukuoka-shi,
   810-0035, Japan, Japan.
EM toyohei_saigusa@yahoo.co.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Empis (Planempis); Empis (Planempis) mandarina [Fujian / Kuatun /
   Systematics]. 
   Empis (Planempis) janssoni; Empis (Planempis) lindebergi [Myanmar /  /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Empididae

   Empis (Planempis) janssoni (Empididae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 63]. 
   Empis (Planempis) lindebergi (Empididae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 60]. 
   Empis (Planempis) mandarina - Frey 1953 (Empididae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 60].

PT J
AN ZOOR14808058466
DT Article
TI Spider wasps (Hymenoptera: Pompilidae) of the Dominican Republic.
AU Waichert, Cecilia (cwaichert@gmail.com) 
   Rodriguez, Juanita
   Von Dohlen, Carol D.
   Pitts, James P.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3353
PS 1-47
PD 21 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3353.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03353p047.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We recorded 33 species in 19 genera of spider wasps from the Dominican
   Republic, of which four species are newly described here: Auplopus
   charlesi Waichert&Pitts, sp. nov., Dipogon (Deuteragenia) marlowei
   Waichert&Pitts, sp. nov., Notocyphus anacaona Rodriguez&Pitts, sp. nov.,
   and Priocnessus vancei Waichert&Pitts, sp. nov. Eight genera are
   reported from the Dominican Republic for the first time: Aporinellus
   Banks, 1912, Caliadurgus Pate, 1946, Dipogon Fox, 1897, Drepanaporus
   Bradley, 1944, Epipompilus Kohl, 1884, Notocyphus Smith, 1855,
   Priocnemis Schiodte, 1837, and Priocnessus Banks, 1925. Nine species are
   new records for the country: Ageniella (Ageniella) bruesi (Banks, 1928),
   Ageniella (Ageniella) violaceipes (Cresson, 1865), Aporinellus medianus
   Banks, 1917, Auplopus bellus (Cresson, 1865), Caliadurgus maestris
   Alayo, 1969, Drepanaporus antillarum (Bradley, 1944), Drepanaporus
   collaris (Cresson, 1865), Epipompilus pulcherrimus (Evans, 1955), and
   Priocnemis cornica (Say, 1836). Pompilus flavopictus Smith, 1862 is a
   junior synonym of Poecilopompilus mixtus (Fabricius, 1794), syn. nov.
   and Odontaporus simulatrix (Bradley, 1944) is junior synonym of
   Drepanaporus collaris (Cresson, 1865), syn. nov. New combination is
   proposed for Aporus (Aporus) antillarum (Bradley, 1944) which is
   transferred to Drepanaporus. Hitherto unknown males of Ageniella
   (Ageniella) domingensis (Banks, 1944) and Drepanaporus antillarum
   (Bradley, 1944) are described and illustrated. Ilustrated keys for
   subfamilies and species of the Dominican Republic pompilids are
   provided.
C1 Waichert, Cecilia; Department of Biology, Utah State University, 5305
   Old Main Hill, Logan, UT 84322-5305, USA, USA.
EM cwaichert@gmail.com
RI Waichert, Cecilia/C-5759-2019; Rodriguez, Juanita/M-6973-2016
OI Waichert, Cecilia/0000-0003-1841-7405; Rodriguez,
   Juanita/0000-0001-9922-1978
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Aporinellus; Caliadurgus; Drepanaporus; Epipompilus; Priocnemis
   [Dominican Republic /  / New record]. 
   Auplopus [West Indies / Caribbean Islands / Key to species]. 
   Auplopus charlesi; Dipogon (Deuteragenia) marlowei; Notocyphus anacaona;
   Priocnessus vancei [Dominican Republic /  / New species]. 
   Dipogon; Notocyphus; Priocnessus [West Indies / Caribbean Islands / Key
   to species] [Dominican Republic /  / New record]. 
   Pepsinae; Pompilinae [Dominican Republic /  / Key to species]. 
   Pompilidae [Dominican Republic /  / Key to subfamilies] [ /  /
   Distribution; new record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Pompiloidea, Pompilidae
OR Pompilidae (Pompiloidea): [Key to subfamilies, Dominican Republic, P. 5;
   New record]. 
   Ageniella (Ageniella) domingensis - (Banks 1944) (Pompilidae): [First
   time described, Male, p. 8]. 
   Aporinellus (Pompilidae): [New record]. 
   Auplopus - Spinola 1841 (Pompilidae): [Key to species, West Indies,
   Caribbean Islands, Females, p. 11]. 
   Auplopus charlesi - Waichert & Pitts 2012 (Pompilidae): [Sp nov,
   Dominican Republic, Host unknown, p. 11].

DT Article
TI NEW BROMELIAD-FEEDING STRYMON SPECIES FROM BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK,
   TEXAS, USA AND ITS VICINITY (LYCAENIDAE: THECLINAE).
AU Grishin, Nick V. (grishin@chop.swmed.edu) 
   Durden, Christopher J.
SO Journal of the Lepidopterists' Society
VL 66
IS 2
PS 81-110
PD Jun 20 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Strymon solitario Grishin&Durden, new species is described from
   southwest Texas, USA. This serapio group species of Strymon is
   distinguished from its closest relatives by a combination of: (1)
   restricted areas of light scales basally from submarginal darker lunules
   on the ventral hindwing-with these light macules not reaching 1/3 of the
   distance between the hinnies and postmedian orange band; (2) small oval
   well-separated orange macules in the postmedian ventral hindwing band;
   (3) the presence of postbasal orange macules on the ventral hindwing in
   some specimens; (4) limited to almost absent violet blue dorsal wing
   overscaling; (5) occasional orange overscaling on the dorsal forewing in
   females; (6) rounder wings, particularly in males; (7) not prominently
   developed areas of dark scales on leg tibiae in most specimens, and (8)
   arid, desert and rocky slopes habitat. Relationships with other Strymon
   species are discussed and life history data are presented and
   illustrated. Hechtia texensis (Bromeliaceae) is established as the
   larval foodplant in the Big Bend National Park area. Over 40 specimens
   and live individuals of the new species are illustrated to show the
   extent of wing pattern variation.
C1 Grishin, Nick V.; Univ Texas SW Med Ctr Dallas, Howard Hughes Med Inst,
   5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas, TX, 75390, USA, USA.
EM grishin@chop.swmed.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0024-0966
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Strymon solitario [Texas /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae
OR Strymon solitario (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, Texas, P. 83]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14810068145
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14809064960
DT Article
TI Terrestrial Malacodiversity of Jinggangshan Nature Reserve.
AU Ouyang, Shan
   Han, Ying-Ying
   Xie, Guang-Long
   Zhao, Jian
   Chen, Chun-Quan
   Lei, Guang-Chun
   Wu, Xiao-Ping (xpwu@ncu.edu.cn) 
SO Chinese Journal of Zoology
VL 47
IS 3
PS 59-65
PD June 20 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species diversity, distribution and fauna geographical elements of
   terrestrial molluscs in Jinggangshan Nature Reserve were analyzed. 67
   species and subspecies (including 9 species unidentified), belonging to
   31 genera (19 families of four orders) were collected, among which
   Sinoennea sp. nov. is new to science and 14 species were new net to
   Jiangxi Province. Referring to the composition of species, the dominant
   species were Diplommatina paxillus longipalatalis, D. apicina,
   Bradybaena ravida ravida and Meghimatium bilineatum; the dominant family
   was Bradybaenidae, with 4 genera and 16 species, accounting for 23. 88%
   of the total diversity. Fauna analysis showed that 43 species belong to
   Oriental, accounting for, 74. 14% of the total diversity. The habitats
   of broad-leaved forest, shrub community and farmland underbrush were
   obviously found with relatively higher terrestrial mollusc species
   richness with comparison to those distributed in bamboo forest and moss.
   Analysis on terrestrial mollusc community characters were made based on
   the Shannon-wiener index, Margalef richness index and Pielou index. The
   species diversity richness of terrestrial mollusc community and richness
   was highest Shrub community,and moss had the highest species Pielou.
   Compared with neighboring nature reserves, Jinggangshan Nature Reserve
   has the most diverse terrestrial molluscs. It was found that the
   terrestrial molluscs in Jinggangshan Nature Reserve had higher species
   similarity with Qiyunshan Nature Reserve and lower similarity with
   Nanling Nature Reserve.
C1 Wu, Xiao-Ping; Nanchang Univ, Coll Life Sci & Food Engn, Nanchang,
   330031, China, China.
EM xpwu@ncu.edu.cn
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0250-3263
BD Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Gastropoda [Community structure /  / ] [Jiangxi / Jinggangshan Nature
   Reserve / ] [ /  / New record]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca
OR Gastropoda (Mollusca): [New record].

AN ZOOR14808058407
DT Article
TI Redescription and neotype designation of Lobogynium sudhiri (Datta)
   (Acari: Diplogyniidae), a mite associated with beetles of the genus
   Atholus (Thomson) (Coleoptera: Histeridae) in the Palaearctic region.
AU Plumari, Massimo (plumari_massimo@libero.it) 
   Kazemi, Shahrooz
SO Zootaxa
VL 3352
PS 1-16
PD 20 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3352.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03352p016.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ophiocelaeno sudhiri Datta, 1985 (family Diplogyniidae) is transferred
   to the genus Lobogynium Tragardh, 1950 and rede- scribed from specimens
   collected in close association with histerid beetles of the genus
   Atholus (Thomson) in Europe and Asia. The genus Lobogynium is redefined
   and a key to the species is presented. The first description of the
   female, detailed redescrip- tion of the male and the new combination
   Lobogynium sudhiri (Datta, 1985) comb. nov. are given. A neotype is
   designated for this species, because the holotype is lost. A strongly
   sclerotised antero-lateral circum-anal area appears to be an
   autapomorphic feature of this species. Lobogynium sudhiri is widely
   distributed in the Palaearctic region, and is probably a
   sapro-coprophilous species that completes its life-cycle in dung and
   other decaying organic matter.
C1 Plumari, Massimo; Civic Museum, 20823 Lentate sul Seveso, Italy, Italy.
EM plumari_massimo@libero.it

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

PT J
AN ZOOR14808058411
DT Article
TI Ahamulina n. gen. (Cestoda: Diphyllidea) from the polkadot catshark,
   Scyliorhinus besnardi (Carcharhiniformes: Scyliorhinidae), off Brazil.
AU Marques, Fernando P.L. (fernando@ib.usp.br) 
   Jensen, Kirsten
   Caira, Janine N.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3352
PS 51-59
PD 20 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3352.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03352p059.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A new genus and species of diphyllidean, Ahamulina catarina n. gen. n.
   sp., is described from the polkadot catshark, Scyliorhi- nus besnardi,
   from Santa Catarina, Brazil. The new genus exhibits apical organ
   armature that is unique among diphyllideans in the arrangement and shape
   of the apical hooks as well as in the lack of lateral hooklets. The
   taxon also exhibits a bipartite cirrus sac. This is the seventh
   diphyllidean reported from a shark, and the third reported from a
   catshark suggesting that the dearth of cestode data for these particular
   sharks belies the true extent of diphyllidean diversity they host.
C1 Marques, Fernando P.L.; Departamento de Zoologia [long dash] IB,
   Universidade de Sao Paulo, Cidade Universitaria, 05508[long dash]090 Sao
   Paulo-S, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fernando@ib.usp.br
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Ahamulina catarina [Piscean hosts / Scyliorhinus besnardi / New parasite
   species] [South Atlantic / Brazil / New species from piscean host]. 
   Scyliorhinus besnardi [Cestode parasites / Ahamulina catarina / New
   parasite species] [South Atlantic / Brazil / New platyhelminth parasite
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Carcharhiniformes, Scyliorhinidae, Platyhelminthes, Cestoda
OR Scyliorhinus besnardi (Scyliorhinidae): [Host]. 
   Ahamulina (Cestoda): [Gen nov, Of order Diphyllidea, Type species
   Ahamulina catarina, p. 53].

DT Article
TI Trichomycterus argos (Teleostei: Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae), a new
   species from the Doce River Basin, Eastern Brazil.
AU Queiroz Lezama, Antonio (anlezama@yahoo.com.br) 
   Triques, Mauro L.
   Santos, Patricia S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3352
PS 60-68
PD 20 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3352.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03352p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Trichomycterus argos, new species, is described from the Rio Doce basin,
   situated in the Serra do Brigadeiro (part of the Serra da Mantiqueira)
   range, southeastern Brazil. The new species is diagnosed by the
   following characteristics: presence of six branched rays in the pectoral
   fin; presence of pelvic fins; tip of nasal barbels extending to
   posterior border of oper- cular plate of odontodes; presence of a large
   foramen for ramus lateralis accessorius facialis, visible in dorsal
   view, in the parietosupraoccipital bone; transverse and straight border
   between the parietosupraoccipital and frontal bones; pectoral- fin ray
   prolonged as a filament; body covered with spots that seldom attain eye
   diameter; pelvic-fin origin placed one or two ocular diameters anterior
   to dorsal-fin origin; abscence of spots fused as elongated marks on
   dorsum or flank.

DT Article
TI A new genus and new species of leucosiid crab (Crustacea: Decapoda:
   Brachyura) from coral reefs in the Indo-West Pacific.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Ng, Peter K.L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3352
PS 40-50
PD 20 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3352.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03352p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and new species of leucosiid crab, Coralliocryptus caementa
   n. sp., is described from Indo-West Pacific coral reefs in the Ryukyu
   Islands (Japan), Vanuatu, and Comoros. Although the new genus exhibits
   superficial resemblance to the Iphiculidae in having prominent vertical
   spiniform teeth on the cutting edges of the chela and the female abdomen
   consisting of freely articulated somites, the deeply excavated female
   sterno-abdominal cavity, which is completely covered by the abdomen,
   unambiguously places this unique taxon in the Leucosiidae. The highly
   eroded, coral-rubble mimic carapace suggests some degree of relationship
   between Coralliocryptus and some other ebaliinine genera, e.g., Alox
   Tan&Ng, 1995, Oreophorus Rup- pel, 1830, Oreotlos Ihle, 1918.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, 955-2
   Aoba-cho, Chuo-ku, Chiba, 260-8682, Japan, Japan.
EM komai@chiba-muse.or.jp
RI Ng, Peter/J-7393-2012
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Coralliocryptus caementa [South Indian Ocean / Mayotte / New species]
   [North Pacific / Japan / ] [South Pacific / Vanuatu / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,

AN ZOOR14808058392
DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Daptonema Cobb, 1920 (Nematoda: Xyalidae)
   found in the monospecific Halophila ovalis patches within an intertidal
   mixed-species seagrass bed on the coast of the Andaman Sea, Thailand.
AU Aryuthaka, Chittima (ffiscta@ku.ac.th) 
   Kito, Kenji
SO Zootaxa
VL 3350
PS 34-45
PD 19 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3350.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03350p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Daptonema hyalocella sp. n. and D. setihyalocella sp. n. are described
   from the Ban Pa Khlok seagrass bed, Phuket Province, Thailand. These new
   species are characterized by the epidermal chords consisting of large
   cells with a transparent appearance, as in D. conicum (Filipjev, 1922)
   and D. trabeculosum (G. Schneider, 1906). The key characteristics of D.
   hyalocella sp. n. are the peculiar epidermal chords, loose S-shaped
   spicules with no proximal cephalation, an indistinct gubernaculum with a
   lateral piece, and two terminal setae. For D. setihyalocella sp. n., the
   key characteristics are similar peculiar epidermal chords, but in this
   case with the L-shaped spicules having proximal cephalation, a distinct
   gubernacu- lum with dorsal apophysis and lateral piece, and four
   terminal setae.
C1 Aryuthaka, Chittima; Department of Marine Science, Faculty of Fisheries,
   Kasetsart University, Bang Khen, Bangkok 10900, Thailand, Thailand.
EM ffiscta@ku.ac.th
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Indian Ocean

   Thailand / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Daptonema hyalocella (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Thailand (marine), P. 36]. 
   Daptonema setihyalocella (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Thailand (marine), P. 40].

DT Article
TI New species and new report of Hyalella S. I. Smith, 1874 (Crustacea:
   Amphipoda: Dogielinotidae) from Minas Gerais state, Southeastern Brazil.
AU Bastos-Pereira, Rafaela (rbastospereira@yahoo.com.br) 
   Bueno, Alessandra Angelica de Padua
SO Zootaxa
VL 3350
PS 58-68
PD 19 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3350.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03350p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB At present, 13 species of Hyalella are recorded from Brazilian
   hydrographic basins. A new species of the genus was found in the
   municipality of Arcos, Minas Gerais state and it is described here.
   Curved seta on inner ramus of male uropod 1, posterior margin of
   gnathopod 2 propodus shorter than palm, telson longer than wide are some
   of the diagnostic charatcters of this new species. The articles of
   maxillipod palp and propodus of gnathopod 2 are elongated as observed in
   H.longistila, but the new species differs from it because of the curved
   seta on uropod 1. Despite being large and diverse group, Hyalella is
   represented only by two species in the state of Minas Gerais
   (Southeastern Brazil), H. warminig and H. gracilicornis. The
   distribution of H. longistila, previously recorded in Rio de Janeiro
   state, was extended to Minas Gerais state. This work, therefore,
   contributes for the knowledge of Amphipoda fauna from Brazil, describing
   a new species and providing a key to the species identification. From
   this work, the number of Hyalella species found in Brazil to 14.
C1 Bastos-Pereira, Rafaela; Universidade Federal de Lavras, Departamento de
   Biologia, Setor de Zoologia Campus Universitario, 37200-000, Lavras,
   Minas Gerais, Brazil, Brazil.
EM rbastospereira@yahoo.com.br
RI Bueno, Alessandra/I-2251-2015

AN ZOOR14808058385
DT Article
TI A new genus of Neotropical Chrysopini (Neuroptera: Chrysopidae).
AU Sosa, Francisco (fransodu73@hotmail.com) 
   De Freitas, Sergio
SO Zootaxa
VL 3351
PS 1-18
PD 19 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3351.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03351p014.pdf
NT Original pagination cited as 1-14.
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Titanochrysa Sosa&Freitas is a new genus of Neotropical Chrysopini
   (Chrysopidae: Chrysopinae) recorded from Costa Rica, Venezuela and
   Brazil. Titanochrysa gen. nov. shares several external and genitalic
   characters with Ceraeochrysa Adams, 1982; Chrysopodes Navas, 1913;
   Cryptochrysa Freitas&Penny, 2000; Parachrysopiella Brooks&Barnard, 1990
   and Ungla Navas 1914. It may be distinguished from those genera by its
   very long sternite 8+9, sternites 2[long dash]8 usually with microtholi,
   male geni- talia with the dorsal surface of the arcessus striated,
   gonosaccus well-developed, bearing elongate gonosetae and microsetae,
   and a spoon-like gonapsis. Herein, Titanochrysa circumfusa (Burmeister,
   1939) (= Chrysopodes circumfusa (Burmeister)) comb. nov. and
   Titanochrysa pseudovaricosa (Penny) (= Ceraeochrysa pseudovaricosa
   Penny, 1998) comb. nov. were identi- fied; Titanochrysa ferreirai
   Sosa&Freitas sp. nov. and Titanochrysa trespuntensis Sosa&Freitas sp.
   nov. were described. The external morphology, and male and female
   genitalia of all these species are described. Titanochrysa circumfusa
   (Burmeis- ter, 1939) comb. nov. is recorded for the first time from
   Venezuela.
C1 Sosa, Francisco; Universidad Centroccidental &quot;Lisandro
   Alvarado&quot;, Museo Entomologico &quot;Dr. Jose Manuel Osorio&quot;,
   Barquisimeto (UCOB), Lara, Venezuela, Venezuela.
EM fransodu73@hotmail.com

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   genus Titanochrysa, p. 7].

   species for new genus, Titanochrysa, p. 2].

AN ZOOR14808058391
DT Article
TI Revision of Australian jumping spider genus Servaea Simon 1887 (Aranaea:
   Salticidae) including use of DNA sequence data and predicted
   distributions.
AU Richardson, Barry J. (barry.richardson@csiro.au) 
   Gunter, Nicole L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3350
PS 1-33
PD 19 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3350.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03350p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Servaea Simon 1887 is revised and redefined. Descriptions and
   identification keys are provided to the following six species, of which
   three are described as new: Servaea incana (Karsch 1878), Servaea
   narraweena n. sp., Servaea melaina n. sp., Servaea spinibarbis Simon
   1909, Servaea villosa (Keyserling 1881) and Servaea zabkai n. sp. The
   type species of the genus, Servaea vestita (L. Koch 1879), is proposed
   here to be a junior synonym of Servaea incana. In addition to the
   diagnoses and descriptions, distributional and nucleotide sequence
   information are provided. DNA sequence data for the segment of COI used
   in other salticid studies was obtained for the five species for which
   suitable material was available. Intraspecific variation in S. villosa
   and S. incana were studied in more detail. Within-species divergence was
   <2% while between-species divergence ranged from 4[long dash]8%. The
   predicted distribution of each species was calculated using BIOCLIM. The
   two small and similar WA species, S. melaina and S spinibarbis, had
   adjacent predicted distributions, one coastal on sandy soils and one
   inland on other soil types.
C1 Richardson, Barry J.; CSIRO Ecosystem Sciences, GPO Box 1700, Canberra,
   ACT 2601, Australia, Australia.
EM barry.richardson@csiro.au
RI Gunter, Nicole L/C-2465-2009
OI Gunter, Nicole L/0000-0002-8355-0862

   Australasia; Australia

   systematics; taxonomic implications] [Divergence /  / ] [Phylogeny /

   [Zoogeography / Predicted species distributions / ] [Australia /  / ]. 
   Servaea melaina [Western Australia /  / New species]. 
   Servaea narraweena [Australian Capital Territory /  / New species] [New
   South Wales /  / ] [Queensland /  / ] [South Australia /  / ] [Victoria
   /  / ]. 
   Servaea zabkai [Queensland /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

OR Servaea - Simon 1887 (Araneae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 12; Key to
   species, Males & females separately keyed, p. 11]. 
   Servaea incana - (Karsch 1878) (Araneae): [Redescription, P. 18]. 
   Servaea melaina (Araneae): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 18]. 
   Servaea narraweena (Araneae): [Sp nov, New South Wales, P. 21]. 
   Servaea obscura - Rainbow 1915 (Araneae): [Nomen dubium, P. 31].

DT Article
TI A new species of Metreletus Demoulin, 1951 from the far eastern region
   of Russia (Ephemeroptera: Ameletidae).
AU Tiunova, Tatiana M. (tiunova@ibss.dvo.ru) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3349
PS 31-39
PD 18 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3349.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03349p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Metreletus omelkoi sp. nov. (male, female imagines and male, female
   subimagines, larvae and egg) is described from the far eastern region of
   Russia. The genus Metreletus Demoulin, 1951 has a trans-Palaearctic
   distribution and includes two species: the West-European mountain
   species, M. balcanicus Ulmer, 1920, and the Far-Eastern species, M.
   micus Bajkova, 1976. Metre- letus omelkoi sp. nov. is the second species
   from Far-Eastern Russia and the third globally. The larvae of M. omelkoi
   sp. nov. differ from the other species in their genus by the size of
   gill I (M. micus) and the form of gills II[long dash]VII (M.
   balcanicus). The male imago of the new species can be distinguished from
   M. balcanicus by shape, the penis lobes.
C1 Tiunova, Tatiana M.; Institute of Biology and Soil Science, Far Eastern
   Branch of Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok 690022, Russia,
   Russia.
EM tiunova@ibss.dvo.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Metretopus omelkoi [Russia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Ephemeroptera
OR Metretopus omelkoi (Ephemeroptera): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 31].

DT Article
TI Hyptia deansi sp. nov., the first record of Evaniidae (Hymenoptera) from
   Mexican amber.
AU Jennings, John T. (john.jennings@adelaide.edu.au) 
   Krogmann, Lars
   Mew, Steven L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3349
PS 63-68
PD 18 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3349.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03349p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Hyptia deansi sp. nov. represents the first record of Evaniidae
   (Hymenoptera) from Lower Miocene to Upper Oligocene Mexi- can amber,
   Simojovel, Chiapas, Mexico and is described based on a well preserved
   female specimen. Phylogenetically relevant morphological characters are
   discussed with reference to fossil and extant genera of Evaniidae. The
   new fossil is placed in the extant New World genus Hyptia Illiger 1807,
   based on the presence of just a single fore wing cell, the absence of
   tubular veins M+CU, 1CUa, 1Cub, and the presence of 11 flagellomeres.
C1 Jennings, John T.; Australian Centre for Evolutionary Biology and
   Biodiversity, The University of Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia, Australia.
EM john.jennings@adelaide.edu.au
OI Jennings, John/0000-0003-3031-6316
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic
DE Evaniidae [Mexico /  / new record; in amber] [Tertiary / Miocene to
   Oligocene / ]. 
   Hyptia deansi [Mexico /  / new species; Described from amber] [Tertiary
   /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Evanioidea, Evaniidae
OR Evaniidae (Evanioidea): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Hyptia deansi (Evaniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, Tertiary, P. 65, Described
   from amber; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Crematogaster brevis complex in Asia (Hymenoptera:
   Formicidae).
AU Hosoishi, Shingo (hosoishi@agr.kyushu-u.ac.jp) 
   Ogata, Kazuo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3349
PS 18-30
PD 18 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3349.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03349p030.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Crematogaster brevis complex is revised and seven species and one
   subspecies, including one new species, are recognized. Two species
   groups are established based on the worker caste. The C. brevis group
   contains two species: brevis Emery, 1887; and overbecki Viehmeyer, 1916.
   The C. treubi group contains five species and one subspecies: bouvardi
   Santschi, 1920. stat. nov.; kojimai sp. nov.; treubi Emery, 1896; treubi
   apilis Forel, 1913; walshi Forel, 1902; and yappi Forel, 1901. The
   following new synonymies are proposed: C. treubi Emery, 1896 = C.
   millardi Forel, 1902 = C. treubi vastatrix Forel, 1911. A key to the
   species based on the worker caste is given. Crematogaster jacobsoni
   Forel, 1911 is transferred to the subgenus Crematogaster.
C1 Hosoishi, Shingo; Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Kyushu University,
   Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan, Japan.
EM hosoishi@agr.kyushu-u.ac.jp

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Taxonomic position; Status; Key; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Crematogaster brevis complex [Asia /  / Taxonomic revision]. 
   Crematogaster kojimai [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Crematogaster (Crematogaster) jacobsoni - Forel 1911 (Formicidae):

   to, Crematogaster (Crematogaster), p. 28]. 
   Crematogaster bouvardi - Santschi 1920 (Formicidae): [Raised from,
   Crematogaster walshi st. bouvardi, p. 22]. 
   Crematogaster brevis - Emery 1887 (Formicidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 22]. 
   Crematogaster brevis complex (Formicidae): [Key to species, Workers, p.
   20]. 
   Crematogaster brevis group (Formicidae): [New species group, P. 19]. 
   Crematogaster kojimai (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 24].

TI Coelindroma Kramer (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Neocoelidiinae) from
   Brazil: description of two new species and new record of C. fungosa.
AU Goncalves, Clayton Correa (clayton.correa.goncalves@gmail.com) 
   Marques-Costa, Ana Paula
   Ale-Rocha, Rosaly
SO Zootaxa
VL 3349
PS 40-47
PD 18 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3349.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03349p047.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of Coelindroma Kramer,1967: Coelindroma cornuta sp. nov.
   and Coelindroma tuberculata sp. nov. are described and illustrated. C.
   cornuta sp. nov. can be distinguished from the other species of the
   genus by the aedeagus with pair of long apical divergent processes;
   while C. tuberculata sp. nov. can be distinguished by the aedeagus with
   pair of short apical convergent processes. C. fungosa Kramer, 1967 is
   recorded from Brazil and an identification key to males of the species
   is provided
C1 Goncalves, Clayton Correa; Coordenacao de Pesquisas em Entomologia,

   69011-970, Manaus-AM, Brazil, Brazil.

VL 1
IS 2
PS 93-100

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The subgenus Allositeroptes Livshits, Mitrofanov and Sharonov, 1986 of
   the genus Siteroptes Amerling (Acari: Pygmephoridae) is considered as
   junior synonym of Krczaldania Sasa, 1961 stat. nov. The subgenus
   Krczaldania Sasa, 1961 is redefined and elevated to a generic rank. The
   type species of the genus Krczaldania - Pygmephorus primitivus Krczal,
   1959, is redescribed based on material from Crimea, Ukraine. A key to
   the known species of the genus Krczaldania is provided.

   South Africa, with description of a new species (Gastropoda:
   Fasciolariidae).

   Fraussen, Koen
SO Miscellanea Malacologica

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new genus Crassibougia is described to accommodate Fusus
   clausicaudatus Hinds, 1844, a species commonly placed in the genus
   Pseudolatirus Bellardi, 1884. Fusus bilineatus Mimes, 1853, a fossil
   from the Italian Miocene and type of the genus Pseudolatirus, is figured
   and briefly discussed. Conchological differences serve to distinguish
   Crassibougia hediae n. sp. from Crassibougia clausicaudatus (Hinds,
   1844) new combination.

TI Tropidosteptes forestierae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Mirinae): A
   New Species of Plant Bug Injuring Ornamental Florida Swampprivet,
   Forestiera segregata (Oleaceae), in South Florida.
AU Henry, Thomas J. (thomas.henry@ars.usda.gov) 
   Caldwell, Doug L.
   Halbert, Susan E.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0240
PS 1-10
PD June 15 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0240Henryetal.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0240Henryetal.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The mirine plant bug Tropidosteptes forestierae, new species (Hemiptera:
   Miridae) is described from Collier County, Florida, where it was found
   causing serious injury to an extensive ornamental hedge of Florida
   swampprivet, Forestiera segregata (Jacq.) Krug and Urb. (Oleaceae).
   Adult male and female, ffth instar, and egg are described. Color images
   of the adults, nymph, egg, and injury; scanning photomicrographs of
   selected adult structures; and illustrations of male genitalia are
   provided. A key to help distinguish the 16 species of Tropidoste- ptes
   known to occur in the southeastern United States is given.
C1 Henry, Thomas J.; Systematic Entomology Laboratory, Agricultural
   Research Service, USDA, c/o P.O. Box 37012, National Museum Natural
   History, MRC-0168, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC 20013-7013,
   USA, USA.

SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354

DT Article
TI Snoqualmia, a new polydesmid milliped genus from the northwestern United
   States, with a description of two new species (Diplopoda, Polydesmida,
   Polydesmidae).
AU Shear, William A. (wshear@hsc.edu) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0238
PS 1-13
PD June 15 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0238Shear.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0238Shear.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Snoqualmia, new genus, is described for two species of polydesmid
   millipeds from the northwestern United States: Snoqualmia snoqualmie,
   new species, from Washington State, and S. idaho, new species, from
   Idaho. Males of S. idaho possess unusually complex gonopods, perhaps the
   most complex to be found in the Order Polydesmida. Snoqualmia is placed
   in context with other polydesmid genera known from North America. The
   polydesmid fauna of North America is discussed, as well as characters of
   the gonopods of the family.
C1 Shear, William A.; Department of Biology, Hampden-Sydney College,
   Hampden-Sydney, VA 23943-0096, USA, USA.

PT J
AN ZOOR14808058176
DT Article
TI Two new free-living nematode species (Comesomatidae) from the
   continental slope of New Zealand, with keys and notes on distribution.
AU Leduc, D. (Daniel.Leduc@niwa.co.nz) 
   Probert, P.K.
   Nodder, S.D.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3348
PS 40-55
PD 15 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3348.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03348p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two new free-living marine nematode species of the family Comesomatidae
   are described from the continental slope of New Zealand, and their
   distributions at 32 sites are investigated in relation to environmental
   factors. Vasostoma aurata n. sp. is characterised by a distinctly
   set-off head, amphideal fovea with 4.5 turns, conspicuous chords
   consisting of two bands fusing at body extremities, with outline of cell
   bodies usually golden-coloured, and relatively short spicules.
   Setosabatieria conicauda n. sp. is characterised by an amphid with
   4.25-4.5 turns, the presence of only 1-3 sub-cephalic setae per file,
   several clusters of intracellular inclusions, sometimes brown-coloured,
   in the intestinal wall, and a conical tail. Keys to all known species of
   Setosabatieria and Vasostoma are provided. Both species were mostly
   restricted to subsurface (1-5cm depth) sediments. The abundance of V.
   aurata n. sp. and S. conicauda n. sp. was significantly correlated with
   food quantity and quality, but the patterns differed between species.
   The effect of food-related factors may be directly linked to
   interspecific differences in food requirements, or mediated by
   biogeochemical processes (i.e., tolerance of sub-surface oxygen and
   sulphide concentrations). No significant correlations were found between
   sediment granulometry and abundances, despite the wide range of sediment
   grain-sizes (6-93% silt and clay) at the sampling sites.
C1 Leduc, D.; Department of Marine Science, University of Otago, P.O. Box
   56, Dunedin, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM Daniel.Leduc@niwa.co.nz
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Setosabatieria conicauda; Vasostoma aurata [South Pacific / New Zealand
   / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Dorylaimopsinae - de Coninck 1965 (Nematoda): [Diagnosis, P. 43]. 
   Sabatieriinae - Filipjev 1934 (Nematoda): [Diagnosis, P. 48]. 
   Setosabatieria - Platt 1985 (Nematoda): [Diagnosis, P. 48; Key to
   species, P. 51]. 
   Setosabatieria conicauda (Nematoda): [Sp nov, New Zealand (marine), P.
   48]. 
   Vasostoma - Wieser 1954 (Nematoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 43; Key to
   species, P. 48]. 
   Vasostoma aurata (Nematoda): [Sp nov, New Zealand (marine), P. 43]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14808058176
DA 2020-09-17

LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The present paper reviews the centipede species of the subgenus
   Lithobius (Sigibius) Chamberlin, 1913 (Lithobiomorpha: Lithobiidae) of
   the Chinese fauna, including a new species Lithobius (Sigibius)
   trichinocaput sp. n. recently discovered from Hebei Province, the only
   East Asian record of this otherwise Central and North America subgenus
   of Lithobiomorpha. Diagnoses of the subgenus and the species, detailed
   account on species distribution and a key to the Chinese Lithobius
   (Sigibius) species are presented.

   southern India (Teleostei: Percomorpha: Badidae).
AU Britz, Ralf (r.britz@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Ali, Anvar
   Philip, Siby
SO Zootaxa
VL 3348
PS 63-68
PD 15 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3348.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03348p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Dario urops, new species, is described from a small stream of the
   Barapole tributary of Valapattanam River in southern Karnataka and from
   Wayanad District, Kerala. It can be distinguished from its congeners by
   the presence of a conspicuous black blotch on the caudal peduncle and a
   horizontal suborbital stripe, by the anterior dorsal fin lappets in
   males not being produced beyond fin spines, and by its vertebral count.

PT J
AN ZOOR14808058175
DT Article
TI Discovery of Aphanipathes verticillata (Cnidaria: Anthozoa:
   Antipatharia) in the Hawaiian Islands.
AU Opresko, D.M. (dmopresko@hotmail.com) 
   Wagner, D.
   Montgomery, A.D.
   Brugler, M.R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3348
PS 24-39
PD 15 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3348.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03348p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Mesophotic coral reef surveys conducted off Maui in 2008-2009 revealed
   several specimens superficially resembling the commercial black coral
   species Antipathes griggi Opresko 2009. After subsequent microscopic
   examination of the skeletal features, these colonies proved to be
   morphologically very similar to Aphanipathes verticillata Brook 1889, a
   species never before reported from the Hawaiian Islands. A comparison
   with samples of the type material of A. verticillata indicated that the
   specimens collected in Hawaiian waters differed from the type in having
   simplier and less dense tubercles on the skeletal spines, a character
   which merits the recognition of the Hawaiian population as a new
   subspecies, A. verticillata mauiensis. Colonies of the new subspecies
   exhibit considerable morphological variation; DNA analysis of fifteen
   specimens ruled out the possibility of the presence of a cryptic
   species. Further DNA investigations on specimens from various localities
   in the western Pacific and Indian Ocean are needed to better understand
   the genetic relationship between the two forms. The morphological
   similarity of A. verticillata mauiensis with Antipathes griggi raises
   questions concerning the validity of past field surveys evaluating the
   population size and structure of A. griggi since it is possible that the
   two species could easily be misidentified based on gross morphology
   alone. Additional studies are also needed to document the geographic and
   bathymetric distribution of the subspecies along the Hawaiian Island
   chain.
C1 Opresko, D.M.; National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian
   Institution, Washington, DC, USA, USA.
EM dmopresko@hotmail.com
RI Montgomery, Anthony/AAK-8138-2020
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Aphanipathes verticillata mauiensis [North Pacific / Hawaii / New
   subspecies]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Ceriantipatharia
OR Aphanipathes - Brook 1889 (Ceriantipatharia): [Diagnosis, P. 26;
   Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P. 36]. 
   Aphanipathes griggi - Opresko 2009 (Ceriantipatharia): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 36]. 
   Aphanipathes verticillata mauiensis (Ceriantipatharia): [Subsp nov,
   Hawaii (marine), P. 30]. 
   Aphanipathes verticillata verticillata - Brook 1889 (Ceriantipatharia):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 26; Description, P. 27]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3348.1.2

TI Catalogue of the Dryinidae and Sclerogibbidae (Hymenoptera:
   Chrysidoidea) of Belize, with description of two new species.
AU Schueepp, Christof
   Olmi, Massimo (olmi@unitus.it) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3346
PS 51-63
PD 14 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3346.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03346p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Eighteen species of Dryinidae and one species of Sclerogibbidae are
   listed from Belize. Two new species of Dryinidae, Anteon dykeae Olmi,
   sp. nov. and Dryinus schueeppi Olmi, sp. nov., are described from
   Belize, Corozal District. Keys to Neotropical species of Anteon and
   Dryinus are modified and include new species. Nine species of Dryinidae
   and one species of Sclerogibbidae are newly recorded from Belize. New
   records of Dryinidae are: four species from Panama, two species from
   Paraguay, and one species from Colombia, Mexico, Honduras, Venezuela,
   Ecuador, Bolivia and French Guiana. The dryinid and sclerogibbid fauna
   of Belize is still under-sampled and insufficiently known.

TI Three new species of Cerviniella Smirnov, 1946 (Copepoda: Harpacticoida)
   from the Arctic.
AU Kihara, Terue C. (Terue-Cristina.Kihara@senckenberg.de) 
   Martinez Arbizu, Pedro
SO Zootaxa
VL 3345
PS 1-33
PD 13 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3345.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03345p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Considered one of the most common harpacticoid families in deep-sea
   benthos, the Aegisthidae can be found in various types of marine
   sediments and at different depths. During the fourth leg of the ninth
   expedition of RV Polarstern in the Arctic Ocean (ARK-IX/4) in September
   1993, three new representatives of the genus Cerviniella were collected
   in multicorer samples from the Laptev Sea at depths of 760-2017 m. The
   new species have a close relationship, as indicated by the combination
   of shared characters: distal segment of antennule with aesthetasc,
   antennary endopod with two setae and one spine laterally, and four
   spines and three setae apically; and the same number of armature
   elements on the maxillula and maxilla. Cerviniella danae sp. nov. and C.
   hitoshii sp. nov. can be easily distinguished from their congeners
   primarily by the reduction of the antennules to only five segments,
   which is common to both species but unique in Cerviniella. Cerviniella
   danae sp. nov. is most readily separated from other described species by
   the armature of the antennule and maxilliped, and the spine and seta
   formulae of the swimming legs. For C. hitoshii sp. nov., major
   diagnostic differences are found in the maxilliped, segmentation and
   setation of P3 and P4 endopods, and P6 represented by three setae.
   Cerviniella arctica sp. nov. is unique in the combination of the
   following characters: caudal rami extremely elongated, armature of the
   antennules and mandible, and the spine and seta formulae of the swimming
   legs. Based on a review of the literature, an updated listing of the
   P1-P4 armature and a key to species of the genus are presented.
C1 Kihara, Terue C.; German Centre for Marine Biodiversity Research (DZMB),
   Senckenberg Research Institute, Suedstrand 44, 26382 Wilhelmshaven,
   Germany, Germany.
EM Terue-Cristina.Kihara@senckenberg.de
